One install gives every supported assistant the same knowledge.\n\n## Installation\n\nThe [skills CLI](https://skills.sh) (by Vercel) detects your installed AI tools and copies the appropriate files to each tool's expected location.\n\n```bash\nnpx skills add triggerdotdev/skills\n```\n\nOr install individual skills:\n\n```bash\nnpx skills add triggerdotdev/skills --skill trigger-tasks\nnpx skills add triggerdotdev/skills --skill trigger-agents\nnpx skills add triggerdotdev/skills --skill trigger-config\nnpx skills add triggerdotdev/skills --skill trigger-realtime\nnpx skills add triggerdotdev/skills --skill trigger-setup\n```\n\n## Available skills\n\n| Skill | Use for | Covers |\n|-------|---------|--------|\n| **trigger-setup** | First time setup, new projects | SDK install, `npx trigger init`, project structure |\n| **trigger-tasks** | Background tasks, async workflows, scheduled tasks | Triggering, waits, queues, retries, cron, metadata |\n| **trigger-agents** | LLM workflows, orchestration, multi-step AI agents | Prompt chaining, routing, parallelization, human-in-the-loop |\n| **trigger-realtime** | Live updates, progress indicators, streaming | React hooks, progress bars, streaming AI responses |\n| **trigger-config** | Project setup, build configuration | `trigger.config.ts`, extensions (Prisma, FFmpeg, Playwright) |\n\nNot sure which to install? Start with `trigger-tasks` â it covers the most common patterns.\n\n## Supported AI assistants\n\nSkills work with any AI coding assistant that supports the [Agent Skills standard](https://agentskills.io), including Claude Code, Cursor, Windsurf, GitHub Copilot, Cline, Codex CLI, Gemini CLI, OpenCode, and [more](https://skills.sh).\n\n## Learn more\n\n- [Skills docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/skills)\n- [Star our skills GitHub repository](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/skills)\n- [Browse all compatible skills on consolidate multiple triggers into a single execution. When triggering a task with a debounce key, subsequent triggers with the same key will reschedule the existing delayed run instead of creating new runs. This continues until no new triggers occur within the delay window.\n\nThis is perfect for scenarios like:\n\n- **User activity updates**: Consolidate rapid user actions into a single processing run\n- **Webhook deduplication**: Handle bursts of webhooks without redundant processing\n- **Search indexing**: Batch document updates instead of processing each change individually\n- **Notification batching**: Group notifications to avoid spamming users\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e Upgrade to SDK 4.3.1+ to use debounced task runs.\n\n## How it works\n\n![Debounced task runs](/changelog/debounced-task-runs/debounced-task-runs-diagram.png)\n\n## Usage\n\n```ts\nawait myTask.trigger(\n  { userId: \"123\" },\n  {\n    debounce: {\n      key: \"user-123-update\",\n      delay: \"5s\",\n    },\n  }\n);\n```\n\n## Options\n\n- **key**: A unique identifier for the debounce group, scoped to the task identifier\n- **delay**: How long to wait before executing (supports duration strings like `\"5s\"`, `\"1m\"`, or milliseconds)\n- **mode**: Either `\"leading\"` (default) or `\"trailing\"`\n\n## Leading vs Trailing mode\n\n**Leading mode** (default): Uses the payload and options from the **first** trigger. Subsequent triggers only push back the execution time.\n\n**Trailing mode**: Uses the payload and options from the **last** trigger. The following options are updated from each new trigger:\n\n- `payload` - The task input data\n- `metadata` - Run metadata\n- `tags` - Run tags (replaces existing tags)\n- `maxAttempts` - Maximum retry attempts\n- `maxDuration` - Maximum compute time\n- `machine` - Machine preset (cpu/memory)\n\n```ts\nawait myTask.trigger(\n  { data: \"latest-value\" },\n  {\n    debounce: {\n      key: \"trailing-example\",\n      delay: \"10s\",\n      mode: \"trailing\",\n    },\n  }\n);\n```\n\n## Behavior notes\n\n- **Idempotency keys take precedence**: If both debounce and idempotency key are specified, idempotency is checked first\n- **Works with triggerAndWait**: Parent runs correctly block on the debounced run.\n\nRead [the full docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/triggering#debounce) for more details.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"How it import, pass, or provide it.\")}return k(w);})();\n;return Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"We've significantly improved our batch trigger system with support for larger payloads, streaming ingestion, and increased batch sizes.\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e Upgrade to SDK 4.3.1+ to use batch trigger v2.\n\n## Updated limits\n\nWith SDK 4.3.1+, batch triggers now support:\n\n| Limit                  | New             | Previous           |\n| ---------------------- | --------------- | ------------------ |\n| Maximum batch size     | **1,000 items** | 500 items          |\n| Batch payload per item | **3MB each**    | 1MB total combined |\n\nPayloads that exceed 512KB are automatically offloaded to object storageâno changes needed in your code.\n\n### Batch trigger rate limits\n\nBatch triggering now uses a token bucket algorithm to rate limit the number of runs you can trigger per environment:\n\n| Pricing tier | Bucket size | Refill rate           |\n| ------------ | ----------- | --------------------- |\n| Free         | 1,200 runs  | 100 runs every 10 sec |\n| Hobby        | 5,000 runs  | 500 runs every 5 sec  |\n| Pro          | 5,000 runs  | 500 runs every 5 sec  |\n\nYou can burst up to your bucket size, then tokens refill at the specified rate. For example, a Free user can trigger 1,200 runs immediately, then must wait for tokens to refill.\n\n### Batch processing concurrency\n\nThe number of batches that can be processed concurrently per environment:\n\n| Pricing tier | Limit                 |\n| ------------ | --------------------- |\n| Free         | 1 concurrent batch    |\n| Hobby        | 10 concurrent batches |\n| Pro          | 10 concurrent batches |\n\n## What's new\n\n### Larger batch sizes\n\nYou can now trigger batches with up to **1,000 items** in a single call (doubled from 500). The system handles large batches efficiently through streaming ingestion, processing items as they arrive rather than waiting for the entire batch.\n\n### Fair processing\n\nWe've implemented a new fair queueing system that ensures multi-tenant fairness with per-environment concurrency limits. This means:\n\n- Your batch triggers won't be starved by other workloads\n- Processing is distributed fairly across all environments in your organization\n- Rate limits use a token bucket algorithm for predictable burst capacity\n\n### Streaming ingestion\n\nLarge batch payloads are now streamed and processed incrementally, reducing memory pressure and improving reliability for high-volume batch operations.\n\n## Usage\n\nBatch triggering works the same way as before:\n\n```ts\nimport { myTask } from \"./trigger/myTask\";\n\n// Trigger a batch of tasks - now supports up to 1,000 items\nconst runs = await myTask.batchTrigger([\n  { payload: { userId: \"user-1\" } },\n  { payload: { userId: \"user-2\" } },\n  { payload: { userId: \"user-3\" } },\n  // ...\n]);\n```\n\nYou can also use `batchTriggerAndWait` to wait for all runs to complete:\n\n```ts\nconst results = await myTask.batchTriggerAndWait([\n  { payload: { userId: \"user-1\" } },\n  { payload: { userId: \"user-2\" } },\n]);\n\nfor (const result of results) {\n  if (result.ok) {\n    console.log(\"Result:\", result.output);\n  }\n}\n```\n\nRead [the full docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/triggering#batch-triggering) for more details.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Updated default for new deployments, improving cold start times when images need to be pulled to worker nodes.\n\n## What's new\n\nThere are two types of cold starts:\n\n- **Fast**: image is already cached on the worker\n- **Slow**: image needs to be pulled from the container registry first\n\nThis change speeds up **slow** cold starts, which are more likely to happen after new deployments, during scale-up events, or when workers are freshly provisioned.\n\nIn production, we've seen image pulls drop by up to 30%. For example, a cold start that previously took 10 seconds now takes ~7 seconds.\n\n## Under the hood\n\nImages now use OCI format with zstd-compressed layers, compatible with all modern container runtimes (containerd 1.5+, Docker 20.10+, CRI-O 1.22+).\n\nZstd compression provides two benefits over the previous gzip default:\n\n- **Smaller images**: 12% reduction in compressed image size\n- **Faster decompression**: 6x quicker, cutting seconds off cold starts\n\n![gzip vs zstd graph](/changelog/zstd-compression/benchmark.png)\n\n## Requirements\n\nTo enable zstd compression re-deploy with version **4.3.0** or later:\n\n```bash\nnpx trigger.dev@latest deploy\n```\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this Deployments will work the same as before, just more reliably.\n\n### Using native builds with the CLI\n\nDeploy with native builds using the `--native-build-server` flag:\n\n```bash\nnpx trigger.dev@latest deploy --native-build-server\n```\n\nBuild logs are streamed directly to the dashboard in real-time, so you can monitor progress of your deployments.\n\nIf you prefer to trigger a deployment without waiting for it to complete, use the `--detach` flag:\n\n```bash\nnpx trigger.dev@latest deploy --native-build-server --detach\n```\n\n\u003cvideo \n  src=\"https://content.trigger.dev/detached.mp4\"\n  controls\n  muted\n  autoPlay\n  loop\n  className=\"rounded border border-charcoal-700\"\n/\u003e\n\n### Using native builds with the GitHub app\n\nIf you're using our GitHub integration for automatic deployments, you can enable native builds from your project's build settings page. Navigate to **Settings \u003e Build Settings** and enable the `Use native build server` option.\n\n## Under the hood\n\n### How it works\n\n1. **Context archiving**: The CLI packages your deployment files into an archive, respecting `.gitignore` rules\n2. **Artifact upload**: The archive is uploaded to our infrastructure via a pre-signed S3 URL\n3. **Server-side build**: Our build server downloads the deployment artifact, installs dependencies and builds the container image\n4. **Event streaming**: Build logs stream back to both the CLI and dashboard in real-time\n\nDeployments to the same environment are queued, only one build per environment runs at a time.\n\n### Caching\n\nWe use AWS ECR as a cache backend to speed up your builds. Image layers are cached between deployments, so subsequent builds only need to rebuild what's changed.\n\nBuild caches are isolated across tenants using IAM policies in ECR.\n\n### Why native builds matter\n\nThis change is an important step in our infrastructure roadmap:\n\n- **Reliability**: Removes dependency on external build providers, reducing points of failure\n- **Control**: Allows us to optimize the build process and integrate tighter with the rest of our infrastructure\n- **Performance**: Opens the door for future build optimizations specific to our platform\n\n## Requirements\n\nNative builds require version **4.2.0** or later. Update your packages:\n\n```bash\nnpx trigger.dev@latest update\n```\n\n## What's next\n\nNative builds will eventually become the default deployment method. We're continuing to optimize build times and reliability as we roll this out more broadly.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this No code changes required.\n\nOfficial release notes: [Bun v1.3.3](https://bun.com/blog/bun-v1.3.3)\n\n## Using Bun in your tasks\n\nTo use Bun for your deployments, set the runtime in your `trigger.config.ts`:\n\n```typescript\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"your-project-ref\",\n  runtime: \"bun\", // Uses Bun v1.3.3\n  // ... other config\n});\n```\n\nThe updated runtime is available for both new deployments and when you redeploy existing projects using Bun.\n\n## Performance impact\n\nEarly testing shows improved cold start times and reduced memory usage, particularly for tasks that import many packages or process large amounts of data. The exact performance gain depends on your specific use case.\n\nIf you're using Node.js and considering switching to Bun, this is a great time to try it - the runtime compatibility has improved significantly with each release.\n","data":{"title":"Bun runtime upgraded to v1.3.3","publishedAt":"2025-12-05T00:00:00.000Z","summary":"We've upgraded the Bun runtime for deployments to v1.3.3, bringing improved performance and the latest features to your Bun-based tasks."},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"What's improved","to":"#whats-improved","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Using Bun in your tasks","to":"#using-bun-in-your-tasks","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Performance impact","to":"#performance-impact","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/bun-v1-3-3-upgrade/bun-v1-3-3-upgrade.mdx"},{"markdown":{"code":"var Component=(()=\u003e{var u=Object.create;var t=Object.defineProperty;var d=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var p=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var y=Object.getPrototypeOf,m=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var g=(r,n)=\u003e()=\u003e(n||r((n={exports:{}}).exports,n),n.exports),b=(r,n)=\u003e{for(var c in n)t(r,c,{get:n[c],enumerable:!0})},a=(r,n,c,o)=\u003e{if(n\u0026\u0026typeof n==\"object\"||typeof n==\"function\")for(let i of p(n))!m.call(r,i)\u0026\u0026i!==c\u0026\u0026t(r,i,{get:()=\u003en[i],enumerable:!(o=d(n,i))||o.enumerable});return r};var w=(r,n,c)=\u003e(c=r!=null?u(y(r)):{},a(n||!r||!r.__esModule?t(c,\"default\",{value:r,enumerable:!0}):c,r)),v=r=\u003ea(t({},\"__esModule\",{value:!0}),r);var l=g((j,s)=\u003e{s.exports=_jsx_runtime});var q={};b(q,{default:()=\u003ef});var e=w(l());function h(r){let n=Object.assign({p:\"p\",h3:\"h3\",ul:\"ul\",li:\"li\",h2:\"h2\",strong:\"strong\",img:\"img\"},r.components);return(0,e.jsxs)(e.Fragment,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:\"First let's talk about the plan changes. Whether you're using the traditional `prisma-client-js` provider or the new Rust-free client architecture, we've got you covered.\n\n## Three modes for every deployment strategy\n\nPrisma is evolving fast. Version 7 introduces a fundamentally different client architecture, moving away from the traditional Rust-based engine (yay!). To support this transition we've rebuilt the extension around three distinct modes:\n\n### Legacy Mode (Prisma 6.x and earlier)\n\nUse this when you're running Prisma 6.x or earlier with the standard `prisma-client-js` provider.\n\n**What's new:**\n\n- Fixes an issue with multi-file schema support\n- Adds support schema location detection from `prisma.config.ts`\n- Enhanced auto-version detection\n\n```ts\nimport { prismaExtension } from \"@trigger.dev/build/extensions/prisma\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"proj_your-project\",\n  build: {\n    extensions: [\n      prismaExtension({\n        mode: \"legacy\",\n        schema: \"prisma/schema.prisma\",\n        migrate: true,\n        typedSql: true,\n        directUrlEnvVarName: \"DATABASE_URL_UNPOOLED\",\n      }),\n    ],\n  },\n});\n```\n\nUse this mode when you're running Prisma 6.x or earlier with the standard `prisma-client-js` provider and no custom output directory.\n\n### Engine-Only Mode (Prisma 6.7+ with custom output)\n\nFor teams using Prisma 6.7+ with a custom output directory but still using the Rust-based engine. This mode gives you control over the client generation process, but will take care of installing the engine binaries for you when deploying.\n\n```ts\nprismaExtension({\n  mode: \"engine-only\",\n  version: \"6.19.0\",\n});\n```\n\n### Modern Mode (Prisma 7+)\n\nThe future is here. Prisma 7's new `prisma-client` removes Rust dependencies entirely, enabling faster installs and simpler deployments.\n\n```ts\nprismaExtension({\n  mode: \"modern\",\n});\n```\n\nBecause of the simplicity of the Prisma 7 client, all this mode does is ensure the `@prisma/client` package is marked as an external dependency and not bundled during our build process, preventing potential issues with cross-module incompatibility.\n\n### Prisma generate\n\nWith both the new `engine-only` and `modern` modes, you will now be responsible for running the `prisma generate` step yourself. Only the `legacy` mode runs this step for you. This simplification brings us more in line with other deployment platforms and simplifies the extension, leading to fewer bugs and edge cases.\n\nSee our [Prisma documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/config/extensions/prismaExtension#manage-your-own-prisma-generate-step) for more information on how to run `prisma generate` when deploying to Trigger.dev.\n\n## Get started today\n\nUpdate to Trigger.dev `4.1.1` to access the new Prisma extension:\n\n```bash\nnpx trigger.dev@latest update\n```\n\nThen update your `trigger.config.ts` to specify the mode that matches your setup. Check out our [Prisma documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/config/extensions/prismaExtension) for detailed configuration examples and migration Join us in our \",(0,t.jsx)(o.a,{href:\"https://trigger.dev/discord\",children:\"Discord community\"}),\" or reach out on \",(0,t.jsx)(o.a,{href:\"https://twitter.com/triggerdotdev\",children:\"Twitter/X\"}),\".\"]})]})}function b(e={}){let{wrapper:o}=e.components||{};return o?(0,t.jsx)(o,Object.assign({},e,{children:(0,t.jsx)(y,e)})):y(e)}var E=b;function d(e,o){throw new Error(\"Expected \"+(o?\"component\":\"object\")+\" `\"+e+\"` to be defined: you likely forgot to import, pass, or provide it.\")}return B(D);})();\n;return Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"If you've ever tried to stream AI completions or real-time data from a long-running task to your frontend, you know the pain: connection drops, arbitrary limits, and wrestling with type safety across your entire stack. Today, we're solving all of that with **Realtime Streams v2**.\n\n## What's new\n\nStreams v2 is a complete overhaul of how you stream data from Trigger.dev tasks, powered by [S2](https://s2.dev). Here's what changed:\n\n| Feature                     | Streams v1   | Streams v2    |\n| --------------------------- | ------------ | ------------- |\n| Maximum stream length       | 2,000 chunks | **Unlimited** |\n| Active streams per run      | 5            | **Unlimited** |\n| Maximum streams per run     | 10           | **Unlimited** |\n| Stream retention            | 1 day        | **28 days**   |\n| Maximum stream size         | 10MB         | **300 MiB**   |\n| Multiple sources per stream | â           | â            |\n| Automatic resumption        | â           | â            |\n\nBut the numbers only tell part of the story. Let's talk about what this means for building real applications.\n\n## The reliability problem\n\nStreaming long-running AI outputs is inherently fragile. Network hiccups happen. Connections drop. In v1, these issues meant lost data and broken streams. Your users would see partial responses, or worse, nothing at all.\n\n**Streams v2 fixes this at the protocol level.** Both sides of the stream (writing from your task and reading from your frontend) now automatically resume from the last successful chunk. Lost your connection for 10 seconds during a 5-minute Claude reasoning task? No problem. The stream picks up right where it left off.\n\nThis isn't a retry mechanism you have to implement. It's built into the core.\n\n## A new developer experience\n\nThe biggest improvement isn't in the infrastructure, it's in how you use it. We've completely rethought the API around a simple idea: **define once, use everywhere with full type safety**.\n\n### Define your streams\n\nInstead of scattering stream keys across your codebase, define them once:\n\n```ts\n// app/streams.ts\nimport { streams, InferStreamType } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\nimport { UIMessageChunk } from \"ai\";\n\nexport const aiStream = streams.define\u003cUIMessageChunk\u003e({\n  id: \"ai\",\n});\n\nexport const progressStream = streams.define\u003c{ step: string; percent: number }\u003e(\n  {\n    id: \"progress\",\n  }\n);\n\n// Export types for your frontend\nexport type AIStreamPart = InferStreamType\u003ctypeof aiStream\u003e;\nexport type ProgressStreamPart = InferStreamType\u003ctypeof progressStream\u003e;\n```\n\nThat's it. Now you have fully-typed, reusable stream definitions that work across your entire application.\n\n### Pipe from your tasks\n\nThe new `streams.pipe()` API replaces `metadata.stream()` with a cleaner, more flexible interface:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\nimport { openai } from \"@ai-sdk/openai\";\nimport { streamText } from \"ai\";\nimport { aiStream, progressStream } from \"@/app/streams\";\n\nexport const generateContent = task({\n  id: \"generate-content\",\n  run: async (payload: { prompt: string }) =\u003e {\n    // Update progress\n    await progressStream.append({ step: \"Starting AI generation\", percent: 0 });\n\n    const result = streamText({\n      model: openai(\"gpt-4o\"),\n      prompt: payload.prompt,\n    });\n\n    // Pipe the AI stream - returns immediately, doesn't block\n    const { stream, waitUntilComplete } = aiStream.pipe(\n      result.toUIMessageStream()\n    );\n\n    // You can iterate locally if needed\n    for await (const chunk of stream) {\n      console.log(\"Chunk generated:\", chunk);\n    }\n\n    // Or just wait for completion\n    await waitUntilComplete();\n\n    await progressStream.append({ step: \"Complete\", percent: 100 });\n\n    return { success: true };\n  },\n});\n```\n\nNotice how we're using the same defined streams? That means:\n\n- **Type safety** - TypeScript knows exactly what type each chunk is\n- **No magic strings** - Stream IDs are centralized\n- **Easy refactoring** - Change the ID once, it updates everywhere\n\n### Read from anywhere\n\nThe real power shows when you consume streams. The same defined stream works in your backend, your frontend, anywhere:\n\n```ts\n// Backend\nimport { aiStream } from \"@/app/streams\";\n\nasync function processInBackend(runId: string) {\n  const stream = await aiStream.read(runId);\n\n  for await (const chunk of stream) {\n    console.log(\"Received:\", chunk); // Fully typed!\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Advanced options\n\nStreams v2 gives you fine-grained control when you need it:\n\n```ts\nconst stream = await aiStream.read(runId, {\n  timeoutInSeconds: 300, // Wait up to 5 minutes\n  startIndex: lastChunk + 1, // Resume from a specific chunk\n  signal: controller.signal, // Cancel with AbortController\n});\n```\n\nThe `startIndex` option is particularly powerful. It lets you implement robust retry logic that resumes exactly where you left off, rather than re-fetching the entire stream.\n\n## React integration: useRealtimeStream\n\nFor frontend developers, we've built a new hook that's as simple as it gets:\n\n```tsx\n\"use client\";\n\nimport { useRealtimeStream } from \"@trigger.dev/react-hooks\";\nimport { aiStream } from \"@/app/streams\";\n\nexport function StreamViewer({ runId, accessToken }) {\n  const { parts, error } = useRealtimeStream(aiStream, runId, {\n    accessToken,\n    timeoutInSeconds: 600,\n    throttleInMs: 50, // Control update frequency\n  });\n\n  if (error) return \u003cdiv\u003eError: {error.message}\u003c/div\u003e;\n  if (!parts) return \u003cdiv\u003eLoading...\u003c/div\u003e;\n\n  return (\n    \u003cdiv\u003e\n      {parts.map((part, i) =\u003e (\n        \u003cspan key={i}\u003e{part}\u003c/span\u003e\n      ))}\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n  );\n}\n```\n\nPass in your defined stream, and you get:\n\n- **Full type safety** - `parts` is typed as your stream's chunk type\n- **Automatic reconnection** - Built into the protocol\n- **Throttled updates** - Don't re-render on every single chunk\n- **Error handling** - Properly typed errors\n\nCompare this to the old `useRealtimeRunWithStreams` hook, which required manual type annotations and returned all streams in a single object. The new hook is focused, type-safe, and declarative.\n\n## Dashboard visibility\n\nStreams are now first-class citizens in the Trigger.dev dashboard. You can:\n\n- **Watch streams in real-time** as your tasks generate them\n- **Inspect historical streams** for completed runs\n- **Debug streaming issues** with full chunk visibility\n\n\u003cvideo\n  src=\"https://content.trigger.dev/streams-v2-dashboard.mp4\"\n  controls\n  muted\n  autoPlay\n  loop\n/\u003e\n\nThis makes debugging production issues dramatically easier. See exactly what your task streamed, when, and in what order.\n\n## Default streams\n\nFor simple cases where you only need one stream per run, you can skip the stream key entirely:\n\n```ts\n// In your task\nconst { waitUntilComplete } = streams.pipe(myStream);\n\n// In your frontend\nconst stream = await streams.read(runId); // Uses the default stream\n```\n\nThis reduces boilerplate while keeping the flexibility to add named streams later.\n\n## Building resumable streams\n\nOne of the most powerful features of Streams v2 is the ability to build truly resilient stream consumption with the `startIndex` option. This lets you resume reading from exactly where you left off, making it trivial to implement retry logic that doesn't re-fetch data:\n\n```ts\nimport { aiStream } from \"@/app/streams\";\n\nasync function consumeStreamWithResumption(runId: string) {\n  let lastChunkIndex = 0;\n  const allChunks: string[] = [];\n  let attempts = 0;\n  const maxRetries = 3;\n\n  while (attempts \u003c maxRetries) {\n    try {\n      // Resume from where we left off\n      const stream = await aiStream.read(runId, {\n        startIndex: lastChunkIndex,\n        timeoutInSeconds: 120,\n      });\n\n      for await (const chunk of stream) {\n        allChunks.push(chunk);\n        lastChunkIndex++;\n      }\n\n      // Success! Break out of retry loop\n      break;\n    } catch (error) {\n      attempts++;\n\n      if (attempts \u003e= maxRetries) {\n        throw new Error(`Failed after ${maxRetries} attempts`);\n      }\n\n      console.log(`Retry attempt ${attempts} from chunk ${lastChunkIndex}`);\n\n      // Exponential backoff\n      await new Promise((resolve) =\u003e\n        setTimeout(resolve, 1000 * Math.pow(2, attempts))\n      );\n    }\n  }\n\n  return allChunks;\n}\n```\n\nThis pattern is incredibly useful for:\n\n- **Long-running AI completions** - 10-minute Claude responses that might hit network issues\n- **Server-side processing** - Background jobs that consume streams without blocking\n- **Batch operations** - Processing thousands of streamed items with guaranteed delivery\n\nThe key insight: the stream is stored durably for 28 days. You can read it whenever you want, from wherever you want, and pick up exactly where you left off. No data loss, no duplicate processing.\n\n## Getting started\n\nStart using streams v2 today by upgrading your packages to **4.1.0 or later**:\n\n```bash\nnpm install @trigger.dev/sdk@latest @trigger.dev/react-hooks@latest\n```\n\nThen follow our [comprehensive guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks/streams) to start defining and using streams.\n\n## Migrating from v1\n\nIf you're using `metadata.stream()`, migration is straightforward:\n\n**Before (v1):**\n\n```ts\nimport { metadata, task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nexport const myTask = task({\n  id: \"my-task\",\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    const stream = getStream();\n    await metadata.stream(\"my-stream\", stream);\n  },\n});\n```\n\n**After (v2):**\n\n```ts\nimport { streams, task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\n// 1. Define your stream\nexport const myStream = streams.define\u003cstring\u003e({\n  id: \"my-stream\",\n});\n\n// 2. Use it in your task\nexport const myTask = task({\n  id: \"my-task\",\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    const stream = getStream();\n    const { waitUntilComplete } = myStream.pipe(stream);\n    await waitUntilComplete();\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThe old API will continue to work, but we recommend migrating to get the benefits of unlimited streams, automatic resumption, and better type safety.\n\n---\n\n**Ready to try it?** Check out our [complete Realtime Streams v2 documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks/streams) or jump straight into our [example projects](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/introduction).\n\nQuestions? Join us in our [Discord community](https://trigger.dev/discord) or reach out on [Twitter/X](https://twitter.com/triggerdotdev).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this Because of this move, we're able to increase the number of logs and spans we can display in the dashboard (up to 50,000 in the Trigger.dev Cloud).\n\n## Under the hood\n\nThis migration represents a fundamental shift in how we store and query OpenTelemetry data. Here's what changed architecturally:\n\n### Why ClickHouse over PostgreSQL?\n\n**Columnar vs Row-based storage**: ClickHouse's columnar storage format is specifically designed for analytical workloads like log aggregation and time-series queries. Unlike PostgreSQL's row-oriented model (optimized for transactional operations), ClickHouse stores data by column, enabling:\n\n- **Massive compression gains**: Similar log attributes compress extremely well when stored together\n- **Faster analytical queries**: Only the columns needed for a query are read from disk\n- **Better aggregation performance**: Sum, count, and group-by operations are significantly faster\n\n**Schema design differences**: Our new ClickHouse schema leverages native partitioning and advanced data types:\n\n```sql\n-- Actual ClickHouse table structure for task events\nCREATE TABLE task_events_v1 (\n    environment_id String,\n    organization_id String,\n    project_id String,\n    task_identifier String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    run_id String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    start_time DateTime64(9) CODEC(Delta(8), ZSTD(1)),\n    trace_id String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    span_id String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    parent_span_id String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    message String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    -- Unified event type classification\n    kind LowCardinality(String) CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    status LowCardinality(String) CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    -- Native JSON type for complex attributes\n    attributes JSON CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    attributes_text String MATERIALIZED toJSONString(attributes),\n    metadata String CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    duration UInt64 CODEC(ZSTD(1)),\n    expires_at DateTime64(3),\n\n    -- Specialized indexes for different query patterns\n    INDEX idx_run_id run_id TYPE bloom_filter(0.001) GRANULARITY 1,\n    INDEX idx_span_id span_id TYPE bloom_filter(0.001) GRANULARITY 1,\n    INDEX idx_duration duration TYPE minmax GRANULARITY 1,\n    INDEX idx_attributes_text attributes_text TYPE tokenbf_v1(32768, 3, 0) GRANULARITY 8\n) ENGINE = MergeTree\nPARTITION BY toDate(start_time)\nORDER BY (environment_id, toUnixTimestamp(start_time), trace_id)\nTTL toDateTime(expires_at) + INTERVAL 7 DAY;\n```\n\n**Performance improvements**: The migration solved the core limitation we hit with PostgreSQL around dynamic attribute search. PostgreSQL's JSON support made it difficult to efficiently search across the varied OpenTelemetry attributes that change per task and span - creating indexes for every possible attribute path wasn't feasible. Searching log messages and attributes required complex PostgreSQL queries that didn't scale well with billions of records, and grouping and filtering by dynamic JSON attributes was slow, making dashboard queries that aggregate across runs impossible.\n\n### Technical implementation details\n\n**Dual-store architecture**: We implemented a feature-flagged approach that allows gradual migration:\n\n- Both PostgreSQL and ClickHouse event repositories implement the same `IEventRepository` interface\n- Environment variables control which store is used for reads/writes\n- This enables zero-downtime migration and easy rollback if needed\n\n**OpenTelemetry data handling**: The new system better handles the unique characteristics of OTEL data:\n\n- **Native JSON attributes**: ClickHouse's `JSON` data type preserves the full structure of OpenTelemetry attributes without flattening, while the materialized `attributes_text` column enables full-text search\n- **Advanced indexing**: Bloom filters for exact ID lookups, token-based full-text search on attributes, and minmax indexes for duration queries\n- **Compression optimizations**: ZSTD compression with delta encoding for timestamps and specialized codecs for different data patterns\n- **Time-based queries**: Most log queries are time-range based, perfectly suited for ClickHouse's date partitioning\n\n**Data consistency model**: Unlike PostgreSQL's ACID guarantees, ClickHouse provides eventual consistency, which is acceptable for observability data where slight delays are tolerable in exchange for massive performance gains.\n\n**Materialized views for metrics**: The ClickHouse migration also enabled us to build real-time usage aggregations using materialized views:\n\n```sql\n-- Pre-aggregated usage metrics by minute and hour\nCREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW mv_task_event_usage_by_minute_v1 AS\nSELECT\n  organization_id,\n  project_id,\n  environment_id,\n  toStartOfMinute(start_time) AS bucket_start,\n  count() AS event_count\nFROM task_events_v1\nGROUP BY organization_id, project_id, environment_id, bucket_start;\n```\n\nThese materialized views automatically maintain real-time usage statistics as events are inserted, powering an upcoming logs metrics feature that will give you insights into your task execution patterns and resource usage without expensive on-the-fly aggregations.\n\n### Migration challenges solved\n\nDuring implementation, we addressed several technical hurdles:\n\n- **Unicode handling**: Implemented safeguards against unpaired Unicode surrogate pairs that could cause ClickHouse insert failures\n- **Async insertions**: Enabled asynchronous insertions to improve write throughput while maintaining data durability\n- **DateTime precision**: Ensured proper handling of nanosecond-precision timestamps (`DateTime64(9)`) for accurate trace correlation\n\nThe result is a system that can efficiently store and query millions of log entries while maintaining the real-time dashboard experience developers expect.\n\n## For self-hosted users\n\nIf youâre running Trigger.dev yourself, youâll need to add a ClickHouse instance to your deployment and enable the new logging backend via environment variables. The migration is non-breaking, and the PostgreSQL event store remains supported until you switch over. Check the [self-hosting guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/self-hosting/overview) for setup details and schema configuration.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On This is useful if you need to temporarily increase the concurrency for a queue or update the concurrency limits programmatically.\n\n## From your task code\n\nYou can override the concurrency limits on a queue by using the `queues.overrideConcurrencyLimit` and `queues.resetConcurrencyLimit` functions.\n\n```ts\nimport { queues } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nexport async function overrideQueueConcurrency() {\n  // Override the concurrency limit to 10\n  const overriddenQueue = await queues.overrideConcurrencyLimit(\n    {\n      type: \"task\",\n      name: \"queues-tester\",\n    },\n    10\n  );\n  \n  // Reset the concurrency limit back to default\n  const resetQueue = await queues.resetConcurrencyLimit({\n    type: \"task\",\n    name: \"queues-tester\",\n  });\n  \n  return { overriddenQueue, resetQueue };\n}\n```\n\n## From the dashboard\n\nYou can override the concurrency limits on a queue by using the \"Override limit\" menu item from an individual queue on the Queues page.\n\n![Override concurrency limits](/changelog/override-concurrency-limits/override-menu-item.png)\n\nSet your concurrency limit and click \"Override limit\". When they're done with the work they can make a POST request to that URL and we'll continue the run with the result.\n\nIt's easier to understand with an example. Here we're going to get [Replicate](https://replicate.com) to generate an image for us in the background.\n\n```ts\nimport { task, wait } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nconst replicate = new Replicate({\n  auth: process.env.REPLICATE_API_KEY,\n});\n\nexport const generateImage = task({\n  id: \"generate-image\",\n  run: async () =\u003e {\n    // You can create this token from your backend or inside a task\n    const token = await wait.createToken({\n      timeout: \"10m\",\n    });\n\n    await replicate.predictions.create({\n      version:\n        \"27b93a2413e7f36cd83da926f3656280b2931564ff050bf9575f1fdf9bcd7478\",\n      input: {\n        prompt: \"A painting of a cat by Andy Warhol\",\n      },\n      // pass the token url to Replicate's webhook, so they can \"callback\"\n      //       ð\n      webhook: token.url,\n      webhook_events_filter: [\"completed\"],\n    });\n\n    const result = await wait.forToken\u003cPrediction\u003e(token).unwrap();\n    // unwrap() throws a timeout error or returns the result ð\n\n    return result;\n  },\n});\n```\n\nWhen Replicate has finished processing the image it will make an HTTP POST request to the URL we gave it. That will complete the Waitpoint and the JSON body is set as the output of the Waitpoint. The run is continued with the output of the Waitpoint.\n\nOn the Cloud product we pause the run when you call `wait.forToken()` (so you stop being charged) and then continue the run when the HTTP callback comes in.\n\n## In the dashboard\n\nOn the waitpoint tokens page you can view the callback URL for each token. They're also shown in the inspector here and on the run logs page.\n\n![Waitpoint tokens page](/changelog/wait-for-http-callback/tokens-page.png)\n\nJust like with regular Waitpoint tokens you can complete and timeout tokens from the inspector:\n\n\u003cvideo\n  src=\"https://content.trigger.dev/manually-complete-waitpoint.mp4\"\n  preload=\"auto\"\n  controls={true}\n  loop\n  muted\n  autoPlay={true}\n  width=\"100%\"\n  height=\"100%\"\n  playsInline={true}\n/\u003e\n\nThis has the same result as calling `wait.completeToken()` or doing an HTTP POST request to the token URL.\n\n## unwrap() vs not unwrapping\n\nIn the code above you might have noticed we used `unwrap()` on the `wait.forToken()` function.\n\nIf an error is thrown then `unwrap()` will throw that error, otherwise the data will just be what you received from HTTP callback. This makes the happy path a lot cleaner. In tasks if you throw an error that isn't caught the attempt will be failed, and retried depending on [your retry settings](https://trigger.dev/docs/errors-retrying).\n\nIf you don't want to use `unwrap()` you get back a Result type:\n\n```ts\nconst result = await wait.forToken\u003cPrediction\u003e(token);\n\nif (!result.ok) {\n  // Handle the error\n  // In this case it's a timeout, since that's the only error that can happen\n} else {\n  // If successful, the data is `result.output`\n  const prediction = result.output;\n}\n```\n\nThis is a bit more boilerplate, but it does give you more control. Generally speaking if you want the run to fail or retry then just use `unwrap()`.\n\n## What can I do with this?\n\nYou can save money with Trigger.dev cloud when you are doing long requests to 3rd parties that support webhook callbacks.\n\nYou can also use this yourself by passing the URL to your API and then making a POST callback when you're ready to continue the run.\n\n![Waitpoint tokens page](/changelog/wait-for-http-callback/tokens-page.png)\n\n## Read the announcement blog post\n\nHTTP callbacks were announced as part of [Launchweek 2](/launchweek/2).\n\n[Read the full announcement post for HTTP callbacks here](/launchweek/2/trigger-v4-ga#http-callbacks)\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this prioritization**: Critical tasks start sooner with priority queuing\n- **Queue management**: Pause environments and get detailed queue statistics\n- **Environment-scoped dashboard**: Better performance and navigation\n- **Middleware and lifecycle hooks**: Shared state with proper cleanup\n- **AI tool integration**: Convert tasks into AI SDK tools\n- **OpenTelemetry exports**: Send logs and traces to external tools\n- **New runtimes**: Bun 1.2.18 and Node.js 22.16.0 support\n- **and more...**\n\n## Migration from v3\n\nMost projects can be migrated in a few minutes with minimal code changes.\n\nOur [migration guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/migrating-from-v3) covers all the necessary steps and breaking changes.\n\n## Read the announcement blog post\n\nTrigger.dev v4 GA was project](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/mastra-agents) demonstrating how to build an AI agent with memory persistence using Mastra and Trigger.dev.\n\n[Mastra](https://mastra.ai/) is a Typescript agent framework for building AI agents. Mastra handles AI agent memory and coordination while Trigger.dev handles orchestration, reliability, observability and scaling.\n\nThe example lets you enter a city and activity to get personalized clothing recommendations based on real-time weather data. Under the hood, it demonstrates:\n\n- **OpenAI GPT-4 powered agents** with specialized roles using Mastra's agent orchestration framework\n- **PostgreSQL memory persistence** enabling data sharing between agents with Zod schema validation\n- **Durable task execution** with Trigger.dev's retry logic, observability, and `triggerAndWait` orchestration\n- **Serverless-ready architecture** using Node.js with Open-Meteo API integration and custom tools\n\n```ts\nexport const whatShouldIWearTodayTask = task({\n  id: \"what-should-i-wear-today\",\n  maxDuration: 15,\n  run: async (payload: { city: string; activity?: string }, { ctx }) =\u003e {\n    const threadId = ctx.run.id;\n\n    // Step 1: Weather agent stores data in shared memory\n    const weatherResult = await weatherDataTask.triggerAndWait({\n      city: payload.city,\n    });\n\n    // Step 2: Clothing agent reads from shared memory\n    const clothingResult = await clothingAdviceTask.triggerAndWait({\n      city: payload.city,\n      activity: payload.activity || \"walking\",\n      threadId: weatherResult.output.threadId,\n    });\n\n    return clothingResult.output;\n  },\n});\n\nexport const weatherDataTask = task({\n  id: \"weather-data\",\n  run: async (payload: { city: string }, { ctx }) =\u003e {\n    const weatherAnalyst = mastra.getAgent(\"weatherAnalyst\");\n\n    const response = await weatherAnalyst.generate(\n      `Get weather for ${payload.city} and store in working memory`,\n      { threadId: ctx.run.id, resourceId: payload.city }\n    );\n\n    return { threadId: ctx.run.id };\n  },\n});\n```\n\nCheck out the [full example](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/mastra-agents) in our GitHub examples repository to see how Mastra's agent OpenTelemetry (OTEL) attribute limits and made them fully configurable for both cloud and self-hosted environments.\n\n## What's changed\n\n**Increased default limits**: Span and log attribute value limits have been raised from **1,024 bytes to 131,072 bytes** (128KB) by default, giving you much more room for detailed telemetry data.\n\n**Smart truncation**: In the Trigger.dev dashboard logs, attributes are still truncated to keep the UI performant, but the full data is preserved in your telemetry pipeline.\n\n**Full configurability**: Self-hosters can now customize all OTEL limits using environment variables, while cloud users can request custom limits from our team.\n\n## Configuration options\n\nFor **self-hosted** deployments, you can now configure these environment variables:\n\n```bash\n# Attribute count limits\nTRIGGER_OTEL_SPAN_ATTRIBUTE_COUNT_LIMIT=256\nTRIGGER_OTEL_LOG_ATTRIBUTE_COUNT_LIMIT=256\n\n# Attribute value length limits (in bytes)\nTRIGGER_OTEL_SPAN_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE_LENGTH_LIMIT=131072\nTRIGGER_OTEL_LOG_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE_LENGTH_LIMIT=131072\n\n# Event and link limits\nTRIGGER_OTEL_SPAN_EVENT_COUNT_LIMIT=10\nTRIGGER_OTEL_LINK_COUNT_LIMIT=2\nTRIGGER_OTEL_ATTRIBUTE_PER_LINK_COUNT_LIMIT=10\nTRIGGER_OTEL_ATTRIBUTE_PER_EVENT_COUNT_LIMIT=10\n```\n\nFor **cloud** users, these limits can be configured per-environment by the Trigger.dev team. [Contact support](https://trigger.dev/contact) if you need custom limits for your use case.\n\n## Why this matters\n\nThe small otel attribute value limits were causing issues when using Trigger.dev with 3rd party otel exporters, particularly [Langfuse](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/trigger.dev/issues/1964), because large AI JSON payloads were being truncated.\n\n## Installation\n\nMake sure you update your `@trigger.dev/sdk` and `trigger.dev` CLI packages to the latest beta version `4.0.0-v4-beta.22`:\n\n```bash\n# Install the latest beta version of the SDK and any other @trigger.dev/* packages\npnpm add @trigger.dev/sdk@4.0.0-v4-beta.22\n# Use the latest beta version of the CLI\npnpm dlx trigger.dev@4.0.0-v4-beta.22\n```\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"What's They can all be forked and used in your own projects.\n\nYou will need to follow the [upgrade to v4 guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/upgrade-to-v4) to use these examples.\n\n## Example projects\n\n### Article summary workflow\n\nCreate audio summaries of newspaper articles!\n\nThis reference project shows a possible approach to implement workflows using [Trigger.dev](https://trigger.dev/) and [ReactFlow](https://reactflow.dev/).\nIt makes use of the Trigger.dev Realtime API and the new [waitpoint primitive](https://trigger.dev/blog/v4-beta-launch#waitpoints) to implement a human-in-the-loop approach for approving the result of an AI workflow.\n\nView the [full project](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/blob/main/article-summary-workflow) on converted to PDF and uploaded to storage.\n\nView the [full project](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/blob/main/vercel-ai-sdk-deep-research-agent) on Github.\n\n\u003cvideo\n column filtering in Trigger.dev Realtime. You can now specify which columns to exclude from your realtime hooks, giving you more control over what data gets sent to your frontend applications.\n\n## Why skip columns?\n\nThere are several scenarios where you might want to exclude certain columns from your realtime hooks:\n\n- **Privacy and security**: Exclude payloads or outputs that may contain sensitive data\n- **Performance optimization**: Skip large text fields, binary data, or other heavy columns to reduce bandwidth and improve streaming performance\n- **Data filtering**: Only stream the specific columns your frontend actually needs, reducing payload size and complexity\n\n## How it works\n\nWhen creating public access tokens or configuring realtime authentication, you can now include a `skipColumns` array in the `realtime` property. This will automatically filter out the specified columns from all realtime data streams using that token:\n\n```typescript\nimport { auth } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nconst publicAccessToken = await auth.createPublicToken({\n  realtime: {\n    skipColumns: [\"payload\", \"output\"],\n  },\n});\n```\n\nBy tying the `skipColumns` to a public access token, you can ensure that only the data you want to stream is sent to your frontend applications, and the value of `skipColumns` cannot be changed after the token is created.\n\nOther columns you may want to skip are:\n\n- `payload` - The payload of the run\n- `output` - The output of the run\n- `costInCents` - The cost of the run in cents\n- `baseCostInCents` - The base cost of the run in cents\n- `durationMs` - The duration of the run in milliseconds\n- `tags` - The tags of the run\n\n## Installation\n\nMake sure you update your `@trigger.dev/sdk` and `trigger.dev` CLI packages to the latest beta version `4.0.0-v4-beta.22`:\n\n```bash\n# Install the latest beta version of the SDK and any other @trigger.dev/* packages\npnpm add @trigger.dev/sdk@4.0.0-v4-beta.22\n# Use the latest beta version of the CLI\npnpm dlx trigger.dev@4.0.0-v4-beta.22\n```\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Why skip This experimental option will keep the task run process alive between run executions, leading to even faster warm starts. This option is respected in both the dev CLI and in deployed tasks.\n\n## Installation\n\nMake sure you update your `@trigger.dev/sdk` and `trigger.dev` CLI packages to the latest beta version `4.0.0-v4-beta.22`:\n\n```bash\n# Install the latest beta version of the SDK and any other @trigger.dev/* packages\npnpm add @trigger.dev/sdk@4.0.0-v4-beta.22\n# Use the latest beta version of the CLI\npnpm dlx trigger.dev@4.0.0-v4-beta.22\n```\n\n## Usage\n\nTo enable this option, add this to your `trigger.config.ts`:\n\n```typescript\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"\u003cproject ref\u003e\",\n  // This is false by default\n  experimental_processKeepAlive: true,\n  maxDuration: 60,\n});\n```\n\nYou can also pass an object to `experimental_processKeepAlive` to provide more options:\n\n```typescript\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"\u003cproject ref\u003e\",\n  experimental_processKeepAlive: {\n    enabled: true,\n    // After 20 runs execute with a single process, we'll restart the process and start fresh\n    maxExecutionsPerProcess: 20,\n    // In dev, you can combine this option with setting a max pool size, giving you the ability to limit the number of processes created on your local dev machine.\n    devMaxPoolSize: 10,\n  },\n  maxDuration: 60,\n});\n```\n\n## Important considerations\n\n- **Memory usage**: Be careful with memory usage and memory leaks, as this will cause memory to persist across run executions.\n- **Process sharing**: It's possible different tasks get executed in the same persisted process.\n- **SDK configuration**: If you configure any 3rd party SDKs globally using env vars for API keys, those SDKs will not change between runs. So if you change an env var between runs, the SDK will be \"stale\" and continue using the old env var value. Instead, you should initialize SDKs using env vars at runtime (in any of the lifecycle hooks or inside the run function of a task).\n- **Task cancellation**: Cancelling a task will cause the task run process to be restarted. Exiting the process is the only reliable way to actually stop a running function from stopping.\n- **Cold starts**: This DOES NOT affect cold starts, warm starts only will be improved.\n\nWe recommend enabling this option and testing in a staging or preview environment before trying it out in prod, as there could be unknown issues depending on what you are doing in your tasks. Create a preview branch\n2. Deploy to the preview branch (1+ times)\n3. Trigger runs using your Preview API key (`TRIGGER_SECRET_KEY`) and the branch name (`TRIGGER_PREVIEW_BRANCH`).\n4. Archive the preview branch when the branch is done.\n\nThere are a few ways to do this:\n\n1. Automatically: using GitHub Actions (recommended).\n2. Use the next build command (recommended)\n3. Manually: in the dashboard and/or using the CLI.\n\n## GitHub Actions\n\nThis Pull Request workflow file will automatically create, deploy, and archive a preview branch for each PR.\n\n```yml .github/workflows/trigger-preview-branches.yml\nname: Deploy to Trigger.dev (preview branches)\n\non:\n  pull_request:\n    types: [opened, synchronize, reopened, closed]\n\njobs:\n  deploy-preview:\n    runs-on: ubuntu-latest\n    steps:\n      - uses: actions/checkout@v4\n\n      - name: Use Node.js 20.x\n        uses: actions/setup-node@v4\n        with:\n          node-version: \"20.x\"\n\n      - name: Install dependencies\n        run: npm install\n\n      - name: Deploy preview branch\n        run: npx trigger.dev@v4-beta deploy --env preview\n        env:\n          TRIGGER_ACCESS_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.TRIGGER_ACCESS_TOKEN }}\n```\n\nYou will need to set the `TRIGGER_ACCESS_TOKEN` (starting with `tr_pat_`) in GitHub so the CLI works â [learn how to create one and set it in GitHub](https://trigger.dev/docs/github-actions#creating-a-personal-access-token).\n\n## Using the next build command\n\nAs shown in the video above, you can modify your existing next build command so when you deploy to Vercel it will deploy to Trigger.dev.\n\n```js package.json\n\"scripts\": {\n  \"build\": \"next build \u0026\u0026 npx trigger.dev@4.0.0-v4-beta.20 deploy --env $VERCEL_ENV\",\n},\n```\n\nThe `$VERCEL_ENV` value here is automatically set to either `production` or `preview` by Vercel. You don't need to set `TRIGGER_PREVIEW_BRANCH` in your Vercel env vars because we read the `VERCEL_GIT_COMMIT_REF` value.\n\nOne caveat with this setup is branches won't get automatically archived because we don't know when the branch is finished with. We have limits on the number of active branches ([depending on your plan](/pricing)). You can manually archive them on the \"Preview branches\" page in the dashboard or you can use the `npx trigger.dev@v4-beta preview archive` CLI command (e.g. from a GitHub action when a PR is closed).\n\n## Triggering runs and using the SDK\n\nYou must set the `TRIGGER_PREVIEW_BRANCH` and `TRIGGER_SECRET_KEY` environment variables in your backend. That allows the SDK to target the correct branch. When using Vercel you don't need to set `TRIGGER_PREVIEW_BRANCH` because we read their `VERCEL_GIT_COMMIT_REF` value.\n\nWhen deploying to somewhere that supports `process.env` (like Node.js runtimes) you can just set the environment variables:\n\n```bash\nTRIGGER_SECRET_KEY=\"tr_preview_1234567890\"\nTRIGGER_PREVIEW_BRANCH=\"your-branch-name\"\n```\n\nIf `process.env` isn't supported you can use our `configure()` function:\n\n```ts\nimport { configure } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\nimport { myTask } from \"./trigger/myTasks\";\n\nconfigure({\n  // WARNING: Never actually hardcode your secret key like this\n  secretKey: \"tr_preview_1234567890\",\n  previewBranch: \"your-branch-name\",\n});\n\nasync function triggerTask() {\n  await myTask.trigger({ userId: \"1234\" }); // Trigger a run in your-branch-name\n}\n```\n\n## Environment variables\n\nYou can set environment variables for \"Preview\" so they are applied to all branches and/or for a specific branch. If a value is set for both it will use the specific branch value.\n\n![Environment variables](/changelog/preview-branches/preview-environment-variables.png)\n\nYou can set environment variables in a few ways:\n\n1. [Manually in the dashboard](https://trigger.dev/docs/deploy-environment-variables#in-the-dashboard)\n2. Using our [syncEnvVars()](https://trigger.dev/docs/config/extensions/syncEnvVars) extension.\n3. Using our [syncVercelEnvVars()](https://trigger.dev/docs/config/extensions/syncEnvVars#syncvercelenvvars) extension.\n\n## Wrapping up\n\nPreview branches mean Trigger.dev works well with your existing git workflows.\n\nRead more about preview branches [in the docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/deployment/preview-branches), read our [v4 upgrade guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/upgrade-to-v4), or [drop into our Discord](https://trigger.dev/discord) with questions.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump This is useful if you want to clean up any resources that were allocated for the run.\n\n```ts\ntasks.onCancel(({ ctx, signal }) =\u003e {\n  console.log(\"Run canceled\", signal);\n});\n```\n\nThe `onCancel` hook can be used to interrupt calls to external services. For example, when using the `streamText` function from the AI SDK:\n\n```ts\nimport { logger, tasks, schemaTask } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\nimport { streamText } from \"ai\";\nimport { z } from \"zod\";\n\nexport const interruptibleChat = schemaTask({\n  id: \"interruptible-chat\",\n  description: \"Chat with the AI\",\n  schema: z.object({\n    prompt: z.string().describe(\"The prompt to chat with the AI\"),\n  }),\n  run: async ({ prompt }, { signal }) =\u003e {\n    const chunks: TextStreamPart\u003c{}\u003e[] = [];\n\n    tasks.onCancel(async () =\u003e {\n      // We have access to the chunks here, and can save them to the database\n      await saveChunksToDatabase(chunks);\n    });\n\n    try {\n      const result = streamText({\n        model: getModel(),\n        prompt,\n        experimental_telemetry: {\n          isEnabled: true,\n        },\n        tools: {},\n        abortSignal: signal, // Pass the signal to the streamText function\n        onChunk: ({ chunk }) =\u003e {\n          chunks.push(chunk);\n        },\n      });\n\n      const textParts = [];\n\n      for await (const part of result.textStream) {\n        textParts.push(part);\n      }\n\n      return textParts.join(\"\");\n    } catch (error) {\n      if (error instanceof Error \u0026\u0026 error.name === \"AbortError\") {\n        // Handle abort error\n      } else {\n        throw error;\n      }\n    }\n  },\n});\n```\n\nYou can also use the `onCancel` hook to wait for the run function to finish and access its output:\n\n```ts\nimport { logger, task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk\";\nimport { setTimeout } from \"node:timers/promises\";\n\nexport const cancelExampleTask = task({\n  id: \"cancel-example\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }, { signal }) =\u003e {\n    try {\n      await setTimeout(10_000, undefined, { signal });\n    } catch (error) {\n      // Ignore the abort error\n    }\n\n    return {\n      message: \"Hello, world!\",\n    };\n  },\n  onCancel: async ({ runPromise }) =\u003e {\n    // You can await the runPromise to get the output of the task\n    const output = await runPromise;\n  },\n});\n```\n\nNote: You have up to 30 seconds to complete the `runPromise` in the `onCancel` hook. working on two things in parallel to bring the new metrics dashboard together. Firstly, a lot of the current dashboard data is being moved to [ClickHouse](https://clickhouse.com/) to allow us to make the dashboard a lot more performant. Secondly, we're building out the new metrics dashboard itself using [Recharts](https://recharts.org/).\n\nHere are some details on the interactivity we're building into the new charts:\n\n1. Rather than overlay a tooltip on the chart, we're going to show a fixed number of legend items below the chart with the total values for the whole chart.\n\n![Metrics preview](/changelog/metrics-preview/1.png?1)\n\n2. If you hover over the legend items, we display the totals for that hovered item. \n\n![Metrics preview](/changelog/metrics-preview/2.png?2)\n\n3. If you hover over a single bar, we show just that bar's value in the legend.\n\n![Metrics preview](/changelog/metrics-preview/3.png?2)\n\n4. If you hover over a bar that's hidden from the legend, we temporarily display it as the last entry.\n\n![Metrics preview](/changelog/metrics-preview/4.png?2)\n\nFinally, we've repurposed the Recharts tooltip for some other thingsâ¦\n\n5. Adding custom rules to Cursor helps you code faster by giving the AI context about your project. Now, writing Trigger.dev tasks should mean fewer trips to the docs with our comprehensive Cursor rules.\n\n## What these rules help you do\n\nThese Cursor rules are specifically designed to help you write Trigger.dev tasks correctly. Here's what they do and don't cover:\n\n| \u003cspan style={{ color: '#28BF5C' }}\u003eHelps with\u003c/span\u003e | \u003cspan style={{ color: '#E11D48' }}\u003eDon't use it for\u003c/span\u003e |\n|------------|---------------|\n| Creating basic tasks | Deploying |\n| Creating scheduled tasks | Project setup |\n| Creating schema tasks | Infrastructure configuration |\n| Triggering tasks from backend | API keys |\n| Task lifecycle functions | Using tags |\n| Using Realtime | |\n| Idempotency patterns | |\n| Metadata handling | |\n| Using build extensions | |\n\n## How to install Cursor rules\n\n1. Locate the `.cursor/rules` folder in your project root\n2. Download the [writing-tasks.mdc](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/trigger.dev/blob/main/.cursor/rules/writing-tasks.mdc) file and place it in the `.cursor/rules` folder\n3. For more help installing Cursor rules, see [Cursor's docs](https://docs.cursor.com/context/rules-for-ai)\n\n\u003cvideo\n  src=\"https://content.trigger.dev/cursor-rules-write-task.mp4\"\n  preload=\"auto\"\n  controls={true}\n  loop\n  muted\n  autoPlay={true}\n  width=\"100%\"\n  height=\"100%\"\n/\u003e\n\n## Tips for making the most of Cursor rules\n\n1. **Turn on Yolo mode** in Cursor settings. This sounds scary, but it just means Cursor will act more like an agent that checks for errors, fixes them, runs commands to install packages, and won't stop until the code is error-free and running. Obviously, worth checking the changes to make sure you're happy.\n\n2. **Explicitly add context when needed** - Cursor should know when to use the rules file, but I recommend selecting it from the \"@ Add context\" button above the prompt window. Then select \"Cursor Rules\" and select your rules file.\n\n3. **Check out [Steve's tweet](https://x.com/steve8708/status/1898074560655962177)** from Builder.io for more tips and tricks on how he uses Cursor.\n\n## New to Trigger.dev?\n\n1. Create a Trigger.dev account at [cloud.trigger.dev](https://cloud.trigger.dev)\n2. Follow the [quick start guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/quick-start) to install Trigger\n3. Download the [cursor rules file](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/trigger.dev/blob/main/.cursor/rules/writing-tasks.mdc)\n\nIf you find anything missing or if it generates incorrect code, let me know! We'll keep these rules updated to be as useful as possible.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump You can then promote the deploy version to the \"current\" version manually using the Trigger.dev dashboard or via the CLI:\n\n```bash\nnpx trigger.dev@latest promote \u003cdeploy-version\u003e\n```\n\n### TRIGGER_VERSION environment variable\n\nYou can now set the `TRIGGER_VERSION` environment variable in your backend and the `@trigger.dev/sdk` will automatically use this version when triggering tasks. This allows you to trigger tasks with a specific version of your Trigger.dev project, enabling atomic deploys between your backend and your Trigger.dev project.\n\nSee our recently updated [deployment overview docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/deployment/overview#current-version) for more about how versions work in Trigger.dev.\n\n### Atomic deploys with Vercel\n\nWe've tested this new feature to prove that atomic deploys are possible with Vercel, and we've written up an [Atomic Deploys guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/deployment/atomic-deployment) in our docs to help you get started.\n\n## Availability\n\nThis feature is available as of version `3.3.17` of the `trigger.dev` and `@trigger.dev/sdk` packages. Please reach out to us on our [Discord](https://trigger.dev/discord) if you have any questions or additional deployment platforms you would like us to provide examples See the \",(0,t.jsx)(o.a,{href:\"https://trigger.dev/docs/config/extensions/pythonExtension#python\",children:\"docs\"}),\" for more information, and please reach out to us on \",(0,t.jsx)(o.a,{href:\"https://trigger.dev/discord\",children:\"Discord\"}),\" if you have any questions or examples you'd like for us to build.\"]})]})}function B(e={}){let{wrapper:o}=e.components||{};return o?(0,t.jsx)(o,Object.assign({},e,{children:(0,t.jsx)(d,e)})):d(e)}var v=B;function y(e,o){throw new Error(\"Expected \"+(o?\"component\":\"object\")+\" `\"+e+\"` to be defined: you likely forgot to import, pass, or provide it.\")}return b(E);})();\n;return Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"Thanks to the work of contributor [Victor Duarte](https://github.com/zvictor), you can now easily include and execute Python scripts in your Trigger.dev tasks with the new `@trigger.dev/python` package.\n\n## Usage\n\nFirst, you'll need to install the `@trigger.dev/python` package:\n\n```bash\nnpm add @trigger.dev/python\n```\n\nThen, you can use the `pythonExtension` build extension in your `trigger.config.ts` file:\n\n```ts\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { pythonExtension } from \"@trigger.dev/python/extension\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"\u003cproject ref\u003e\",\n  build: {\n    extensions: [pythonExtension()],\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThis will take care of adding python to the build image and setting up the necessary environment variables to execute Python scripts. You can then use our `python` utilities in the `@trigger.dev/python` package to execute Python scripts in your tasks. For example, running a Python script inline in a task:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { python } from \"@trigger.dev/python\";\n\nexport const myScript = task({\n  id: \"my-python-script\",\n  run: async () =\u003e {\n    const result = await python.runInline(`print(\"Hello, world!\")`);\n    return result.stdout;\n  },\n});\n```\n\n## Adding python scripts\n\nYou can automatically add python scripts to your project using the `scripts` option in the `pythonExtension` function. This will copy the specified scripts to the build directory during the deploy process. For example:\n\n```ts\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { pythonExtension } from \"@trigger.dev/python/extension\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"\u003cproject ref\u003e\",\n  build: {\n    extensions: [\n      pythonExtension({\n        scripts: [\"./python/**/*.py\"],\n      }),\n    ],\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThis will copy all Python files in the `python` directory to the build directory during the deploy process. You can then execute these scripts using the `python.runScript` function:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { python } from \"@trigger.dev/python\";\n\nexport const myScript = task({\n  id: \"my-python-script\",\n  run: async () =\u003e {\n    const result = await python.runScript(\"./python/my_script.py\", [\n      \"hello\",\n      \"world\",\n    ]);\n    return result.stdout;\n  },\n});\n```\n\n## Using requirements files\n\nIf you have a `requirements.txt` file in your project, you can use the `requirementsFile` option in the `pythonExtension` function to install the required packages during the build process. For example:\n\n```ts\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { pythonExtension } from \"@trigger.dev/python/extension\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"\u003cproject ref\u003e\",\n  build: {\n    extensions: [\n      pythonExtension({\n        requirementsFile: \"./requirements.txt\",\n      }),\n    ],\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThis will install the packages specified in the `requirements.txt` file during the build process. You can then use these packages in your Python scripts.\n\n## Virtual environments\n\nIf you are using a virtual environment in your project, you can use the `devPythonBinaryPath` option in the `pythonExtension` function to specify the path to the Python binary in the virtual environment. For example:\n\n```ts\nimport { defineConfig } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { pythonExtension } from \"@trigger.dev/python/extension\";\n\nexport default defineConfig({\n  project: \"\u003cproject ref\u003e\",\n  build: {\n    extensions: [\n      pythonExtension({\n        devPythonBinaryPath: \".venv/bin/python\",\n      }),\n    ],\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThis has no effect in production mode, but in development mode, it will use the specified Python binary to execute Python scripts.\n\n## Streaming output\n\nAll of the `python` functions have a streaming version that allows you to stream the output of the Python script as it runs. For example:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { python } from \"@trigger.dev/python\";\n\nexport const myStreamingScript = task({\n  id: \"my-streaming-python-script\",\n  run: async () =\u003e {\n    // You don't need to await the result\n    const result = python.stream.runScript(\"./python/my_script.py\", [\n      \"hello\",\n      \"world\",\n    ]);\n\n    // result is an async iterable/readable stream\n    for await (const chunk of streamingResult) {\n      console.log(chunk);\n    }\n  },\n});\n```\n\n## Environment variables\n\nWe automatically inject the environment variables in the `process.env` object when running Python scripts. You can access these environment variables in your Python scripts using the `os.environ` dictionary. For example:\n\n```python\nimport os\n\nprint(os.environ[\"MY_ENV_VAR\"])\n```\n\nYou can also pass additional environment variables to the Python script using the `env` option in the `python.runScript` function. For example:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { python } from \"@trigger.dev/python\";\n\nexport const myScript = task({\n  id: \"my-python-script\",\n  run: async () =\u003e {\n    const result = await python.runScript(\n      \"./python/my_script.py\",\n      [\"hello\", \"world\"],\n      {\n        env: {\n          MY_ENV_VAR: \"my value\",\n        },\n      }\n    );\n    return result.stdout;\n  },\n});\n```\n\n## Availability\n\nThis package requires the `@trigger.dev/sdk` package version 3.3.17 or higher. See the [docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/config/extensions/pythonExtension#python) for more information, and please reach out to us on [Discord](https://trigger.dev/discord) if you have any questions or examples you'd like for us to build.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump Now you can receive alerts via webhooks when runs fail, deployments fail, or deployments succeed. This complements our existing email and Slack notification options.\n\n## How it works\n\nYou can now setup webhook alerts through our dashboard and handle them in your application using our SDK. When an alert is triggered, we'll send a POST request to your specified endpoint with details about the event.\n\n### Setting up webhook alerts\n\n1. Navigate to the \"Alerts\" section in the dashboard\n2. Click \"New alert\"\n3. Select \"Webhook\" as your alert method\n4. Choose which events you want to receive alerts for:\n   - Run failures\n   - Deployment failures\n   - Deployment successes\n5. Enter your webhook URL\n6. Copy the generated webhook secret - you'll need this to verify webhooks\n\n### Handling webhooks\n\nHere's how to handle webhook alerts in your application using the Trigger.dev SDK. In this exammple, we're using the Remix framework:\n\n```ts\nimport { ActionFunctionArgs, json } from \"@remix-run/server-runtime\";\nimport { webhooks, WebhookError } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport async function action({ request }: ActionFunctionArgs) {\n  if (request.method !== \"POST\") {\n    return json({ error: \"Method not allowed\" }, { status: 405 });\n  }\n\n  try {\n    const event = await webhooks.constructEvent(request, process.env.ALERT_WEBHOOK_SECRET!);\n\n    // Handle different alert types\n    switch (event.type) {\n      case \"alert.run.failed\": {\n        console.log(\"Run failed alert received\", { event });\n        break;\n      }\n      case \"alert.deployment.success\": {\n        console.log(\"Deployment succeeded alert received\", { event });\n        break;\n      }\n      case \"alert.deployment.failed\": {\n        console.log(\"Deployment failed alert received\", { event });\n        break;\n      }\n    }\n\n    return json({ received: true });\n  } catch (err) {\n    if (err instanceof WebhookError) {\n      return json({ error: err.message }, { status: 400 });\n    }\n    return json({ error: \"Internal server error\" }, { status: 500 });\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Why is this useful?\n\nWebhook alerts allow you to:\n- Build custom alert handling logic\n- Integrate alerts with your existing monitoring systems\n- Automate responses to failed runs or deployments\n- Track deployment success/failure rates\n\n## Next steps\n\nCheck out our [Alerts documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/troubleshooting-alerts) to learn more about setting up alerts. If you have questions or need help, join us on [Discord](https://trigger.dev/discord) or reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/triggerdotdev).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"How it This can happen when you're processing large files, images, video, or other data that requires a lot of memory.\n\nBefore we talk about the new retry feature, we need to talk about machines in general.\n\n## Machines\n\nWe support specifying the [machine](https://trigger.dev/docs/machines) in a few different ways. Larger machines have more memory (and vCPUs).\n\nSpecifying the machine for a task:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const heavyTask = task({\n  id: \"heavy-task\",\n  // This is how you specify the machine for a task\n  machine: \"large-1x\",\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    //...do heavy stuff\n  },\n});\n```\n\nYou can also override the task machine when you trigger it:\n\n```ts\nawait heavyTask.triggerAndWait({ message: \"hello world\" }, { machine: \"large-2x\" });\n```\n\nThis is useful when you know that a certain payload will require more memory than the default machine. For example, you know it's a larger file or a customer that has a lot of data.\n\n## Retry OOM errors\n\nIf you are seeing a lot of OOM errors then you need to either optimize your code to use less memory or increase the machine size, as described above.\n\nHowever, there are situations where you want to automatically retry an OOM failure on a larger machine. This is where the new retry feature comes in:\n\n```ts\nimport { task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const heavyTask = task({\n  id: \"heavy-task\",\n  // It will use this machine by default\n  machine: \"medium-1x\",\n  retry: {\n    // If the task fails with an OOM error, it will retry on this machine\n    outOfMemory: {\n      machine: \"large-1x\",\n    },\n  },\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    //...do heavy stuff\n  },\n});\n```\n\nIf an attempt fails with an OOM error, the run will automatically retry on the machine you specify. If the larger machine fails again with an OOM error, it won't retry again because it won't succeed.\n\nRuns will always start with the default machine, and only retry on the specified machine if they fail with an OOM error.\n\n\u003e [!IMPORTANT]\n\u003e This is great when you have a small percentage of OOM errors for a task and you want to automatically retry them on a larger machine. But bear in mind that this isn't efficient because you have to get an OOM error first for this to kick in. That means you've wasted some compute time on the smaller machine.\n\n\n## Upgrading to 3.3.14+\n\nUpdate to 3.3.14 or higher to use this new retry feature. Read our [how to upgrade guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/upgrading-packages).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Machines","to":"#machines","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Retry OOM errors","to":"#retry-oom-errors","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Upgrading to 3.3.14+","to":"#upgrading-to-3314","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/retry-oom-errors/retry-oom-errors.mdx"},{"markdown":{"code":"var Component=(()=\u003e{var g=Object.create;var o=Object.defineProperty;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var m=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var p=Object.getPrototypeOf,u=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var f=(r,e)=\u003e()=\u003e(e||r((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),b=(r,e)=\u003e{for(var i in e)o(r,i,{get:e[i],enumerable:!0})},s=(r,e,i,n)=\u003e{if(e\u0026\u0026typeof e==\"object\"||typeof e==\"function\")for(let a of m(e))!u.call(r,a)\u0026\u0026a!==i\u0026\u0026o(r,a,{get:()=\u003ee[a],enumerable:!(n=c(e,a))||n.enumerable});return r};var x=(r,e,i)=\u003e(i=r!=null?g(p(r)):{},s(e||!r||!r.__esModule?o(i,\"default\",{value:r,enumerable:!0}):i,r)),w=r=\u003es(o({},\"__esModule\",{value:!0}),r);var l=f((y,h)=\u003e{h.exports=_jsx_runtime});var k={};b(k,{default:()=\u003ej});var t=x(l());function d(r){let e=Object.assign({p:\"p\",a:\"a\",h3:\"h3\",ul:\"ul\",li:\"li\"},r.components);return(0,t.jsxs)(t.Fragment,{children:[(0,t.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[\"Check out our \",(0,t.jsx)(e.a,{href:\"https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples\",children:\"examples GitHub repo\"}),\" for projects to learn more about how to use Trigger.dev. Feel free to fork the repo and use the code in your own projects.\n\n### Examples\n\nProjects we have added so far:\n\n- [Building effective agents](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/building-effective-agents) - an example Node.js project showcasing common AI agent patterns. We've also written a blog post about it [here](/blog/ai-agents-with-trigger).\n- [Batch LLM evaluator](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/batch-llm-evaluator) - This example Next.js project generates an image from a prompt using Fal.ai and shows the progress of the task on the frontend using Trigger.dev Realtime.\n- [Next.js Server Actions](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/nextjs-server-actions) - This is a full working example of a Next.js app with a Trigger.dev task triggered using a Server Action.\n- [Next.js webhooks](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/nextjs-webhooks) - This project shows you how to set up a webhook handler in a Next.js project which triggers a task once a webhook is received.\n- [Realtime CSV importer](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/realtime-csv-importer) - A full stack example that demonstrates how to use Trigger.dev Realtime to build a CSV Uploader with live progress updates.\n- [Realtime Fal AI image generator](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/realtime-fal-ai-image-generation) - This example project generates an image from a prompt using Fal.ai and shows the progress of the task on the frontend using Trigger.dev Realtime.\n- [Remix webhooks](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/remix-webhooks) - This project shows you how to set up a webhook handler in a Remix project which triggers a task once a webhook is received.\n- [Triggering tasks from Supabase edge functions](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/supabase-edge-functions) - trigger tasks from Supabase edge functions and Supabase Database Webhooks when your database changes.\n\n### Star the repo\n\nWe will be adding more examples over time, so [star our examples repo](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples) to get notifications as we add more.\n\n### Contributions\n\nWe also welcome contributions, so if you have an example project you'd like to share with the community, please open a
