This is useful when you have a task that triggers another task, which triggers another task, and so on. The `metadata.root` will always point to the top-level parent task.\n\n```ts\nimport { task, metadata } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const myParentTask = task({\n  id: \"my-parent-task\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }) =\u003e {\n    // Do some work\n    metadata.set(\"progress\", 0.1);\n\n    // Trigger a child task\n    await childTask.triggerAndWait({ message: \"hello world\" });\n  },\n});\n\nexport const childTask = task({\n  id: \"child-task\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }) =\u003e {\n    // In this case, metadata.root and metadata.parent are the same\n    metadata.root.set(\"progress\", 0.5);\n\n    await grandChildTask.triggerAndWait({ message: \"hello world\" });\n  },\n});\n\nexport const grandChildTask = task({\n  id: \"grand-child-task\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }) =\u003e {\n    // This will update the root task's metadata to set the progress to 0.9\n    metadata.root.set(\"progress\", 0.9);\n  },\n});\n```\n\nAll of the update methods are available on `metadata.parent` and `metadata.root`:\n\n```ts\nmetadata.parent.set(\"progress\", 0.5);\nmetadata.parent.append(\"logs\", \"Step 1 complete\");\nmetadata.parent.remove(\"logs\", \"Step 1 complete\");\nmetadata.parent.increment(\"progress\", 0.4);\nmetadata.parent.decrement(\"otherProgress\", 0.1);\nmetadata.parent.stream(\"llm\", readableStream);\n\nmetadata.root.set(\"progress\", 0.5);\nmetadata.root.append(\"logs\", \"Step 1 complete\");\nmetadata.root.remove(\"logs\", \"Step 1 complete\");\nmetadata.root.increment(\"progress\", 0.4);\nmetadata.root.decrement(\"otherProgress\", 0.1);\nmetadata.root.stream(\"llm\", readableStream);\n```\n\nYou can also chain the update methods together:\n\n```ts\nmetadata.parent\n  .set(\"progress\", 0.1)\n  .append(\"logs\", \"Step 1 complete\")\n  .increment(\"progress\", 0.4)\n  .decrement(\"otherProgress\", 0.1);\n```\n\n## Why is this useful?\n\nThis feature is useful when you have a parent task that triggers child tasks and you want to update the parent task's metadata based on the child task's progress. This allows you to have a single source of truth for the progress of the entire task tree. Combined with our [Realtime API](https://trigger.dev/docs/realtime), you can build powerful dashboards that show the progress of all tasks in a task tree in real-time.\n\n## Example\n\nWe've built an example \"CSV importer\" full-stack app that triggers a child task for each row in the CSV file. The child task updates the parent task's metadata with the progress of the import:\n\n\u003cvideo\n  src=\"https://content.trigger.dev/csv-upload-realtime-metadata.mp4\"\n  preload=\"auto\"\n  controls={true}\n  muted\n  autoPlay={false}\n  width=\"100%\"\n  height=\"100%\"\n/\u003e\n\nYou can find the full example in our [examples repository](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/examples/tree/main/realtime-csv-importer)\n\n## Next steps\n\nCheckout our [Metadata docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/runs/metadata) to learn more about how you can use metadata in your tasks. If you have any questions or need help, feel free to reach out to us on [our Discord channel](https://trigger.dev/discord) or message us on [X/Twitter](https://twitter.com/triggerdotdev).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Overview","to":"#overview","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Why is this useful?","to":"#why-is-this-useful","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Example","to":"#example","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Next steps","to":"#next-steps","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/metadata-parent-root-updates/metadata-parent-root-updates.mdx"},{"markdown":{"code":"var Component=(()=\u003e{var a=Object.create;var s=Object.defineProperty;var u=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var g=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var f=Object.getPrototypeOf,m=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var w=(t,e)=\u003e()=\u003e(e||t((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),p=(t,e)=\u003e{for(var r in e)s(t,r,{get:e[r],enumerable:!0})},l=(t,e,r,o)=\u003e{if(e\u0026\u0026typeof e==\"object\"||typeof e==\"function\")for(let i of g(e))!m.call(t,i)\u0026\u0026i!==r\u0026\u0026s(t,i,{get:()=\u003ee[i],enumerable:!(o=u(e,i))||o.enumerable});return t};var y=(t,e,r)=\u003e(r=t!=null?a(f(t)):{},l(e||!t||!t.__esModule?s(r,\"default\",{value:t,enumerable:!0}):r,t)),x=t=\u003el(s({},\"__esModule\",{value:!0}),t);var h=w((k,c)=\u003e{c.exports=_jsx_runtime});var b={};p(b,{default:()=\u003eT});var n=y(h());function d(t){let e=Object.assign({p:\"p\",ul:\"ul\",li:\"li\",strong:\"strong\",code:\"code\",a:\"a\"},t.components);return(0,n.jsxs)(n.Fragment,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:\"It's important that you can quickly find the runs you want. If you have any feedback or feature requests, please let us know on our \",(0,o.jsx)(e.a,{href:\"https://feedback.trigger.dev/\",children:\"feedback board\"}),\" or reach out to us on \",(0,o.jsx)(e.a,{href:\"https://x.com/triggerdotdev\",children:\"x\"}),\" or \",(0,o.jsx)(e.a,{href:\"https://trigger.dev/discord\",children:\"Discord\"}),\".\"]})]})}function B(t={}){let{wrapper:e}=t.components||{};return e?(0,o.jsx)(e,Object.assign({},t,{children:(0,o.jsx)(d,t)})):d(t)}var v=B;function u(t,e){throw new Error(\"Expected \"+(e?\"component\":\"object\")+\" `\"+t+\"` to be defined: you likely forgot to import, pass, or provide it.\")}return b(w);})();\n;return Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"Today we're releasing three new revolutionary features that will change the way you use Trigger.dev forever:\n\n- **Realtime API**: Subscribe to runs and get live updates on the run status.\n- **Public access tokens**: Share your runs with the world using public access tokens.\n- **React hooks**: Easily integrate Trigger.dev into your React applications.\n\nSo, three things: a realtime API, a way to share your runs with the world, and React hooks.\n\nA realtime API, a way to share your runs with the world, and React hooks.\n\nA realtime API, a way to share your runs with the world... are you getting it?\n\n![stove jibs](/changelog/realtime-beta/background-steve-jobs.jpg)\n\nThese are not three separate features. This is one feature, and we are calling it **Trigger.dev Realtime** (okay actually it is three separate features).\n\n## What is Trigger.dev Realtime?\n\nTrigger.dev Realtime has been our [#1 requested feature](https://feedback.trigger.dev/p/realtime-notifications) since v3 launched. It allows you to subscribe to runs and get live updates on the run status and more, from your backend or frontend. It's a bridge between your background tasks running on Trigger.dev and your frontend applications.\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e We don't currently support sending streaming responses (e.g. from OpenAI) through the Realtime API. This is something that is planned for a future release.\n\n## Realtime API\n\nThe Realtime API is built on top of [Electric SQL](https://electric-sql.com/), an open-source PostgreSQL syncing engine. The Trigger.dev API wraps Electric SQL and provides a simple API to subscribe to [runs](https://trigger.dev/docs/runs) and get real-time updates.\n\nAfter you trigger a task, you can subscribe to the run using the `runs.subscribeToRun` function. This function returns an async iterator that you can use to get updates on the run status.\n\n```ts\nimport { runs, tasks } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\n// Somewhere in your backend code\nasync function myBackend() {\n  const handle = await tasks.trigger(\"my-task\", { some: \"data\" });\n\n  for await (const run of runs.subscribeToRun(handle.id)) {\n    // This will log the run every time it changes\n    console.log(run);\n  }\n}\n```\n\nEvery time the run changes, the async iterator will yield the updated run. You can use this to update your UI, log the run status, or take any other action.\n\nAlternatively, you can subscribe to changes to any run that includes a specific tag (or tags) using the `runs.subscribeToRunsWithTag` function.\n\n```ts\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\n// Somewhere in your backend code\nfor await (const run of runs.subscribeToRunsWithTag(\"user:1234\")) {\n  // This will log the run every time it changes, for all runs with the tag \"user:1234\"\n  console.log(run);\n}\n```\n\nYou will receive updates whenever a run changes for the following reasons:\n\n- The run moves to a new state or completes.\n- [Run tags](https://trigger.dev/docs/tags) are added or removed.\n- [Run metadata](https://trigger.dev/docs/runs/metadata) is updated.\n\n## Public access tokens\n\nWhile you can subscribe to runs from your backend, we've also added a way for you to selectively expose your runs to the your frontend through public access tokens.\n\nWhen you create a public access token, you can specify which runs it can access. You can then use this token to subscribe to runs from your frontend.\n\n```ts\nimport { auth } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n// Somewhere in your backend\nconst publicToken = await auth.createPublicToken({\n  scopes: {\n    read: {\n      runs: [\"run_1234\"],\n    },\n  },\n});\n\n// Somewhere in your frontend\nimport { auth } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nauth.configure({\n  accessToken: publicToken,\n});\n\nfor await (const run of runs.subscribeToRun(\"run_1234\")) {\n  // This will log the run every time it changes\n  console.log(run);\n}\n```\n\nPublic access tokens are just JWTs with the necessary scopes to access the runs you specify. You can use them to subscribe to runs from your frontend, or even share them with others to let them subscribe to your runs. And they don't just work with the Realtime API; you can use them with any Trigger.dev API that supports public access token authentication (which at the moment is just the Realtime API and the [runs.retrieve()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/runs/retrieve) endpoint).\n\nWe'll also auto-generate public access tokens for you when you trigger a task:\n\n```ts\nimport { tasks } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport type { myTask } from \"./trigger/tasks\";\n\n// Somewhere in your backend\nconst handle = await tasks.trigger(\"my-task\", { some: \"data\" });\n\n// This will log the public access token that can be used to subscribe to the run\nconsole.log(handle.publicAccessToken);\n```\n\n## React hooks\n\nFinally, we're releasing a new `@trigger.dev/react-hooks` package to make it easy to integrate the Trigger.dev Realtime API into your React applications.\n\n```tsx\nimport React from \"react\";\nimport { useRealtimeRun } from \"@trigger.dev/react-hooks\";\n\nfunction MyComponent() {\n  const { run, error } = useRealtimeRun(\"run_1234\");\n\n  if (error) {\n    return \u003cdiv\u003eError: {error.message}\u003c/div\u003e;\n  }\n\n  return \u003cdiv\u003e{JSON.stringify(run)}\u003c/div\u003e;\n}\n```\n\n## Runs + tags + metadata = flexible real-time updates\n\nWe've built the Realtime API on top of existing Trigger.dev features like runs, tags, and run metadata. This means you can use tags to subscribe to multiple runs at once, and you can use run metadata to provide custom realtime updates, outside of the run status and output. As a little demonstration of what is capable with this, we've built a simple Next.js app that combines [UploadThing](https://uploadthing.com/) and [fal.ai](https://fal.ai/) with Trigger.dev Realtime and put together a little walkthrough of how it works:\n\n\u003cdiv className=\"aspect-video h-full w-full\"\u003e\n  \u003ciframe\n    width=\"100%\"\n    height=\"100%\"\n    src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/RhJAbSGkS88?si=4Z72SfygeklNI3As\"\n    title=\"YouTube video player\"\n    frameborder=\"0\"\n    allow=\"accelerometer; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"\n    referrerpolicy=\"strict-origin-when-cross-origin\"\n    allowfullscreen\n  \u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\n## Get started today\n\nThe Realtime API is available in beta now in version `3.1.0` of the Trigger.dev SDK. We're labelling it `beta` because we're still working on it, and we'd love to hear your feedback. Checkout our [documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/realtime) to get started.\n\nIf you are self-hosting Trigger.dev, you will need to upgrade to server version `3.1.0` to use the Realtime API and version `0.7.5` of the Electric SQL server to use the Realtime API. See our [self-hosting docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/open-source-self-hosting) for more information.\n\n## Other changes\n\n3.1.0 also includes a few other changes \u0026 additions:\n\n### Sync run metadata\n\nWe've updated the [Run metadata API](https://trigger.dev/docs/runs/metadata) to better support Realtime updates by making the metadata API synchronous, and batching metadata updates in the background. This means you will be able to call `metadata.set` or `metadata.replace` hundreds of times per second without any performance impact. Previously, these calls were asynchronous and would update the run immediately, which could cause performance issues if you were updating metadata frequently.\n\n### Schema Tasks\n\nWe've added a new task type that we're calling `schemaTask` that allows you to define a validation schema for the payload of a task:\n\n```ts\nimport { schemaTask } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { z } from \"zod\";\n\nconst myTask = schemaTask({\n  id: \"my-task\",\n  schema: z.object({\n    name: z.string(),\n    age: z.number(),\n  }),\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    console.log(payload.name, payload.age);\n  },\n});\n```\n\nWe'll infer the type of the payload in the `run` function from the schema you provide, and we'll validate the payload before running the task. If the payload doesn't match the schema, we'll throw an error. In addition to a custom schema parser function, we're shipping with support for the following schema libraries:\n\n- [Zod](https://zod.dev/)\n- [valibot](https://valibot.dev/)\n- [Yup](https://github.com/jquense/yup)\n- [Superstruct](https://github.com/ianstormtaylor/superstruct)\n- [ArkType](https://arktype.io/)\n- [@effect/schema](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@effect/schema)\n- [runtypes](https://github.com/runtypes/runtypes)\n- [typebox](https://github.com/sinclairzx81/typebox)\n\nSee our [documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks/schemaTask) for more information.\n\n## What's next?\n\nWe're excited to see what you build with Trigger.dev Realtime. We're already working on some improvements, like adding support for streaming responses from services like OpenAI, and we're investigating integrating React Server Components to make it even easier to build real-time applications with Trigger.dev. If you have any feedback or feature requests, please let us know on our [feedback board](https://feedback.trigger.dev/) or reach out to us on [x](https://x.com/triggerdotdev) or [Discord](https://trigger.dev/discord).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"What is                                                    | Description                                                                    |\n| :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\n| [DALLÂ·E 3 image generation](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/dall-e3-generate-image)          | Use OpenAI's GPT-4o and DALLÂ·E 3 to generate an image and text.                |\n| [FFmpeg video processing](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/ffmpeg-video-processing)           | Use FFmpeg to process a video in various ways and save it to Cloudflare R2.    |\n| [OpenAI with retrying](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/open-ai-with-retrying)                | Create a reusable OpenAI task with custom retry options.                       |\n| [PDF to image](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/pdf-to-image)                                 | Use `MuPDF` to turn a PDF into images and save them to Cloudflare R2.          |\n| [Puppeteer](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/puppeteer)                                       | Use Puppeteer to generate a PDF or scrape a webpage.                           |\n| [React to PDF](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/react-pdf)                                    | Use `react-pdf` to generate a PDF and save it to Cloudflare R2.                |\n| [Resend email sequence](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/resend-email-sequence)               | Send a sequence of emails over several days using Resend with Trigger.dev.     |\n| [Sharp image processing](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/sharp-image-processing)             | Use Sharp to process an image and save it to Cloudflare R2.                    |\n| [Stripe webhook](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/stripe-webhook)                             | Trigger a task from Stripe webhook events.                                     |\n| [Supabase database operations](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/supabase-database-operations) | Run basic CRUD operations on a table in a Supabase database using Trigger.dev. |\n| [Supabase Storage upload](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/supabase-storage-upload)           | Download a video from a URL and upload it to Supabase Storage using S3 client. |\n| [Vercel AI SDK](https://trigger.dev/docs/guides/examples/vercel-ai-sdk)                               | Use Vercel AI SDK to generate text using OpenAI.                               |\n\n[Let us You can use metadata to store additional, structured information on a run. For example, you could use metadata to update the progress of a run.\n\n## Usage\n\nAdd metadata to a run by passing it as an object to the `trigger` function:\n\n```ts\nconst handle = await myTask.trigger(\n  { message: \"hello world\" },\n  { metadata: { user: { name: \"Eric\", id: \"user_1234\" } } }\n);\n```\n\nThen inside your run function, you can access the metadata like this:\n\n```ts\nimport { task, metadata } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const myTask = task({\n  id: \"my-task\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }) =\u003e {\n    const user = metadata.get(\"user\");\n    console.log(user.name); // \"Eric\"\n    console.log(user.id); // \"user_1234\"\n  },\n});\n```\n\nYou can also update the metadata during the run:\n\n```ts\nimport { task, metadata } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const myTask = task({\n  id: \"my-task\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }) =\u003e {\n    // Do some work\n    await metadata.set(\"status\", {\n      state: \"running\",\n      progress: 0.1,\n      message: \"Starting\",\n    });\n\n    // Do some more work\n    await metadata.set(\"status\", {\n      state: \"running\",\n      progress: 0.5,\n      message: \"Halfway there\",\n    });\n\n    // Do even more work\n    await metadata.set(\"status\", {\n      state: \"running\",\n      progress: 0.9,\n      message: \"Almost done\",\n    });\n\n    // Finish up\n    await metadata.set(\"status\", {\n      state: \"complete\",\n      progress: 1,\n      message: \"Done\",\n    });\n  },\n});\n```\n\nAccess the metadata outside of a task via the API:\n\n```ts\n// Somewhere in your backend code\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nasync function main() {\n  const run = await runs.retrieve(\"run_1234\");\n  console.log(run.metadata.user.name); // \"Eric\"\n  console.log(run.metadata.user.id); // \"user_1234\"\n}\n```\n\nLearn all about how to use metadata in the [metadata documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/runs/metadata).\n\n## Updating\n\nRun metadata is available as of version `3.0.8` of the SDK. To update, run:\n\n```sh\nnpx trigger.dev@latest update\n```\n\nIf you are self-hosting Trigger.dev, you will need to update to version [3.0.8](https://github.com/triggerdotdev/trigger.dev/releases/tag/v.docker.3.0.8) or later. See our [self-hosting updating docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/open-source-self-hosting#updating) for more information.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Usage","to":"#usage","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Updating","to":"#updating","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/run-metadata/run-metadata.mdx"},{"markdown":{"code":"var Component=(()=\u003e{var m=Object.create;var r=Object.defineProperty;var u=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var b=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var g=Object.getPrototypeOf,x=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var j=(e,t)=\u003e()=\u003e(t||e((t={exports:{}}).exports,t),t.exports),p=(e,t)=\u003e{for(var n in t)r(e,n,{get:t[n],enumerable:!0})},c=(e,t,n,s)=\u003e{if(t\u0026\u0026typeof t==\"object\"||typeof t==\"function\")for(let a of b(t))!x.call(e,a)\u0026\u0026a!==n\u0026\u0026r(e,a,{get:()=\u003et[a],enumerable:!(s=u(t,a))||s.enumerable});return e};var f=(e,t,n)=\u003e(n=e!=null?m(g(e)):{},c(t||!e||!e.__esModule?r(n,\"default\",{value:e,enumerable:!0}):n,e)),h=e=\u003ec(r({},\"__esModule\",{value:!0}),e);var d=j((y,i)=\u003e{i.exports=_jsx_runtime});var w={};p(w,{default:()=\u003e_});var o=f(d());function l(e){let t=Object.assign({p:\"p\",a:\"a\"},e.components);return(0,o.jsxs)(t.p,{children:[\"Trigger.dev v3 is now generally available and out of beta. If you get an error from OpenAI that you've hit your token limit you can [retry when they tell you your tokens will be refilled](https://trigger.dev/docs/errors-retrying#openai-error-handling-example).\n\n### Why attempt alerts were the wrong choice\n\nThe reason I mention all of this is because you should try and make your tasks very resilient to failure using retries. If you do this, reattempts should (in most cases) mean your run succeeds in the end.\n\nPreviously we had alerts when a run attempt failed. This meant you got a lot of extra alerts that didn't mean a run had failed and it was unclear when you needed to actually pay attention.\n\nWe've changed these to be run failure alerts instead. When a run has failed and won't reattempt anymore you'll get an alert, if you subscribe.\n\nWe support three channels at the moment:\n\n- Slack\n- Email\n- Webhook\n\nYou can read [the docs here](https://trigger.dev/docs/troubleshooting-alerts) for how to add alerts to your project. We also support alerts for deployments succeeding and failing.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":3,"title":"Advanced automatic retries","to":"#advanced-automatic-retries","children":[]},{"depth":3,"title":"Why attempt alerts were the wrong choice","to":"#why-attempt-alerts-were-the-wrong-choice","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/alert-run-failures/alert-run-failures.mdx"},{"markdown":{"code":"var Component=(()=\u003e{var h=Object.create;var o=Object.defineProperty;var a=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var g=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var p=Object.getPrototypeOf,m=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var y=(t,e)=\u003e()=\u003e(e||t((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),f=(t,e)=\u003e{for(var i in e)o(t,i,{get:e[i],enumerable:!0})},l=(t,e,i,s)=\u003e{if(e\u0026\u0026typeof e==\"object\"||typeof e==\"function\")for(let r of g(e))!m.call(t,r)\u0026\u0026r!==i\u0026\u0026o(t,r,{get:()=\u003ee[r],enumerable:!(s=a(e,r))||s.enumerable});return t};var x=(t,e,i)=\u003e(i=t!=null?h(p(t)):{},l(e||!t||!t.__esModule?o(i,\"default\",{value:t,enumerable:!0}):i,t)),j=t=\u003el(o({},\"__esModule\",{value:!0}),t);var u=y((R,d)=\u003e{d.exports=_jsx_runtime});var k={};f(k,{default:()=\u003ew});var n=x(u());function c(t){let e=Object.assign({p:\"p\",a:\"a\",h3:\"h3\",ul:\"ul\",li:\"li\"},t.components);return(0,n.jsxs)(n.Fragment,{children:[(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[\"We've put together a detailed guide on how to use Trigger.dev with Next.js. If you had a long run, e.g. with a `await wait.for({ days: 7 })`, then your logs could be deleted before the run had even completedâ¦ not good.\n\nNow the timer starts when the run completes, so you can be sure that your logs will be around for the full retention period.\n\n## The run inspector when logs are deleted\n\nNow you can always view the run details in the inspector, even if the logs have been deleted. Below that we show a timeline with the events that have happened for that run (so far).\n\nWe've also pulled the payload, output and errors onto the \"Overview\" tab.\n\n![The new run inspector](/changelog/run-page-inspector/run-page-inspector-overview.jpg?2)\n\nThe \"Detail\" tab has a full list of data relevant to the run (including [tags](/changelog/run-tags) and [usage data](/changelog/usage-and-billing)).\n\nThe \"Context\" tab has the run context that you can access inside the `run` function (in the second param).\n\n## Replaying a run\n\nWe've added support for replaying a run from the dashboard with a different payload and environment.\n\n![The new run inspector](/changelog/run-page-inspector/run-page-replay.png?2)\n\nThis works for runs where the payload was JSON or SuperJSON. Here we're adding up the total compute cost for an organization using our [usage tracking](https://trigger.dev/docs/run-usage):\n\n```ts\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nasync function getComputeDollarCostForOrg(orgId: string) {\n  let totalCost = 0;\n\n  // This loops through every single run matching the tag and status\n  for await (const run of runs.list({\n    tag: orgId,\n    status: [\"COMPLETED\"],\n  })) {\n    // Use our usage data to calculate the total cost\n    totalCost += run.costInCents + run.baseCostInCents;\n  }\n\n  return totalCost / 100;\n}\n```\n\n## What are tags?\n\nTags are strings between 1 and 64 characters long that can be attached to a run. You can add up to 3 tags to each run when you trigger and/or during the run.\n\nHere are some example tags:\n\n- `user_123456`: the user ID associated with the run.\n- `org_654321`: the organization ID associated with the run.\n- `subscriber`, `free-trial`: for the type of user the run belongs to.\n\nWe strongly recommend that you prefix your tags with the type at the beginning using an underscore or colon, like `user_123456`. This makes it easier to filter and search for tags â we also make them look nicer in the dashboard:\n\n![Tagging runs in the dashboard](/changelog/run-tags/run-tags-example.png)\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e Lots of popular APIs already prefix their IDs so you can just throw them into\n\u003e your tags. Stripe for example uses `cus_123456` for customers.\n\n## How to add tags\n\nYou can [add tags to a run when you trigger it](https://trigger.dev/docs/tags#1-adding-tags-when-triggering-the-run):\n\n```ts\nconst handle = await myTask.trigger(\n  { message: \"hello world\" },\n  // A string or an array of up to 3 strings\n  { tags: [\"user_123456\", \"org_abcdefg\"] }\n);\n```\n\nOr you can [add tags during a run](https://trigger.dev/docs/tags#2-adding-tags-inside-the-run-function):\n\n```ts\nimport { task, tags } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const myTask = task({\n  id: \"my-task\",\n  run: async (payload: { message: string }, { ctx }) =\u003e {\n    // Get the tags from when the run was triggered using the context\n    // This is not updated if you add tags during the run\n    logger.log(\"Tags from the run context\", { tags: ctx.run.tags });\n\n    // Add tags during the run (a single string or array of strings)\n    await tags.add(\"product_1234567\");\n  },\n});\n```\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e Remember the total tags on a run are limited to 3. So if you trigger with 2 tags you can only add 1 more during the run.\n\n## Updating to beta 51\n\nYou need to ensure your packages are at least `@trigger.dev/sdk@3.0.0-beta.51` to use tags. Read our [upgrading packages guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/upgrading-packages) for the fastest way to do that.\n\nFor the full details on tags, check out our [tags documentation](https://trigger.dev/docs/tags).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this page","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"What You can attach schedules to a `schedules.task` in the dashboard and dynamically using the SDK. This allows you to build some powerful things like recurring tasks for your users (using `externalId`).\n\nBut what if you want a scheduled task with an attached cron pattern in your code that syncs when you make changes? That's our new declarative cron feature.\n\n## Declaring a cron pattern\n\n```ts\nimport { logger, schedules } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const checkMetrics = schedules.task({\n  id: \"check-metrics\",\n  //6am every day\n  cron: \"0 6 * * *\",\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    const formattedTime = payload.timestamp.toLocaleString(\"en-US\");\n    logger.log(formattedTime);\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThat `cron` property is an optional property you can add to a `schedules.task`. If you leave it off then schedules work as before (you add them explicitly in the dashboard or using the SDK).\n\nIf you add it then a schedule will be synced whenever you run the [dev](https://trigger.dev/docs/cli-dev) or [deploy](https://trigger.dev/docs/cli-deploy) commands with the CLI (including in GitHub Actions). We sync when the cron property is added, updated, or removed.\n\n## With a timezone\n\nUTC can be painful to work with so we also support adding a timezone:\n\n```ts\nimport { logger, schedules } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const checkMetrics = schedules.task({\n  id: \"check-metrics\",\n  //6am every day in New York\n  cron: {\n    pattern: \"0 6 * * *\",\n    timezone: \"America/New_York\",\n  },\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    const formattedTime = payload.timestamp.toLocaleString(\"en-US\", {\n      //use the timezone to format the time\n      timeZone: payload.timezone,\n    });\n\n    logger.log(formattedTime);\n  },\n});\n```\n\nJust like when specifying the timezone using our imperative functions, this respects Daylight Saving Time changes. You can see a full list of [timezones we support](https://cloud.trigger.dev/timezones).\n\n## Declarative vs Imperative schedules\n\nThis new type of cron schedule is \"declarative\" and our existings one are \"imperative\".\n\nDeclarative schedules can only be created, updated, or removed by editing your `schedules.task` `cron` property in your code and then syncing by running `dev` or `deploy`. You cannot modify them in the dashboard or using the imperative SDK functions.\n\nEach environment gets a separate declarative schedule â if you run the dev and deploy commands you'll end up with two schedules in the dashboard (one for dev and one for prod). If you run deploy with [the staging flag](https://trigger.dev/docs/cli-deploy#environment-env-or-e) then you'll get another. This means you won't accidentally alter a production schedule when you're working in dev.\n\nGenerally we recommend using declarative schedules for your internal tasks and imperative schedules for your user-facing tasks. This is because declarative schedules are easier to manage and track in your codebase.\n\nRead [the full docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks-scheduled) for all the options and functions available on schedules.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Declaring a cron Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"We've shipped an improvement to our SDK retry logic when calling functions like `tasks.trigger`, `runs.retrieve`, etc. Previously, if the SDK received a rate limit error from the API, it would use a simple exponential backoff strategy to retry the request.\n\nIt went a little something like this:\n\n- Request: GET /runs/run_1233\n- Response: 429 Rate Limit Error\n- Retry GET /runs/run_1233 after 1 second\n- Response: 429 Rate Limit Error\n- Retry GET /runs/run_1233 after 2 seconds\n- Response: 429 Rate Limit Error\n- Retry GET /runs/run_1233 after 4 seconds\n- Response: 429 Rate Limit Error\n- Throw an error\n\nLuckily, the Trigger.dev API server uses standard ratelimit headers to communicate the rate limit status back to the client, including the `x-ratelimit-reset` header that tells the client when the rate limit will reset. This update now uses that header to wait until the rate limit resets before retrying the request:\n\n- Request: GET /runs/run_1233\n- Response: 429 Rate Limit Error\n- Wait until `x-ratelimit-reset` time\n- Retry GET /runs/run_1233\n- Response: 200 OK\n\nWe've also updated our API server to use a different rate limit strategy. Previously, we used the [Sliding Window](https://upstash.com/docs/oss/sdks/ts/ratelimit/algorithms#sliding-window) strategy, but that could lead to long periods of rate limiting if a client made a burst of requests. We've now switched to the [Token Bucket](https://upstash.com/docs/oss/sdks/ts/ratelimit/algorithms#token-bucket) strategy, which should provide shorter delays between requests.\n\n### Task retries\n\nWe've also updated the retry logic for tasks that fail with a rate limit error from our SDK. As an example, let's imagine this task that fetches a run:\n\n```ts\nimport { runs, task } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nexport const taskRetries = task({\n  id: \"task-retries\",\n  retry: {\n    maxAttempts: 5,\n    minTimeoutInMs: 500,\n    maxTimeoutInMs: 30_000,\n    factor: 1.8,\n  },\n  run: async (payload: { runId: string }, { ctx }) =\u003e {\n    // We override the default retry logic so this call with throw a RateLimitError\n    await runs.retrieve(payload.runId, {\n      retry: {\n        maxAttempts: 1,\n      },\n    });\n  },\n});\n```\n\nWhen the above task runs, and the `runs.retrieve` call fails with a rate limit error, the task will now wait until the rate limit resets before attempting to retry the task.\n\n### Custom request options\n\nBy default, the SDK will retry requests up to 3 times, with an exponential backoff delay between retries.\n\nYou can customize the retry behavior by passing a `requestOptions` option to the `configure` function:\n\n```ts\nimport { configure } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nconfigure({\n  requestOptions: {\n    retry: {\n      maxAttempts: 5,\n      minTimeoutInMs: 1000,\n      maxTimeoutInMs: 5000,\n      factor: 1.8,\n      randomize: true,\n    },\n  },\n});\n```\n\nAll SDK functions also take a `requestOptions` parameter as the last argument, which can be used to customize the request options. You can use this to disable retries for a specific request:\n\n```ts\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nasync function main() {\n  const run = await runs.retrieve(\"run_1234\", {\n    retry: {\n      maxAttempts: 1, // Disable retries\n    },\n  });\n}\n```\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e When running inside a task, the SDK ignores customized retry options for certain functions (e.g., `task.trigger`, `task.batchTrigger`), and uses retry settings optimized for task execution.\n\n### SDK OpenTelemetry spans\n\nThe SDK now outputs OpenTelemetry spans for all SDK functions (previously we only emitted spans for task triggering). This includes any retry waits.\n\nThe following example tells the story. Note that I ran this against my local Trigger.dev instance and configured the API server to randomly respond with a 500 response 25% of the time:\n\n```ts\nexport const sdkSpans = task({\n  id: \"sdk-spans\",\n  run: async () =\u003e {\n    logger.log(\"Starting spans subtask without a runId\");\n    const handle = await sdkSpansSubtask.trigger({});\n    logger.log(\"Starting spans subtask with a runId\", { runId: handle.id });\n    await sdkSpansSubtask.triggerAndWait({ runId: handle.id });\n  },\n});\n\nexport const sdkSpansSubtask = task({\n  id: \"sdk-spans-subtask\",\n  run: async (payload: { runId?: string }) =\u003e {\n    await wait.for({ seconds: 5 });\n\n    if (payload.runId) {\n      logger.log(\"Retrieving run\", { runId: payload.runId });\n      const run = await runs.retrieve(payload.runId);\n      logger.log(\"Cancelling run\", { runId: run.id });\n      await runs.cancel(run.id);\n      logger.log(\"Replaying run\", { runId: run.id });\n      await runs.replay(run.id);\n    }\n\n    await wait.for({ seconds: 30 });\n  },\n});\n```\n\nAs you can see in the screenshot, all calls to the SDK functions are logged and includes spans for the retries:\n\n![SDK spans with waits](/changelog/auto-ratelimit-retries/sdk-spans.png)\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"On this The `delay` option accepts a number of different formats:\n\n```ts\n// Delay the task run by 1 hour\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { delay: \"1h\" });\n// Delay the task run by 88 seconds\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { delay: \"88s\" });\n// Delay the task run by 1 hour and 52 minutes and 18 seconds\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { delay: \"1h52m18s\" });\n// Delay until a specific time\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { delay: \"2024-12-01T00:00:00\" });\n// Delay using a Date object\nawait myTask.trigger(\n  { some: \"data\" },\n  { delay: new Date(Date.now() + 1000 * 60 * 60) }\n);\n```\n\nYou can also pass a `delay` option when batch triggering tasks:\n\n```ts\nawait myTask.batchTrigger([\n  { payload: { some: \"data\" }, options: { delay: \"1h\" } },\n  { payload: { some: \"data\" }, options: { delay: \"2h\" } },\n  { payload: { some: \"data\" }, options: { delay: \"15m\" } },\n]);\n```\n\nYou can also reschedule a task that has a delay set by calling `runs.reschedule`:\n\n```ts\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\n// The delay option here takes the same format as the trigger delay option, and will be re-calculated from the current time\nawait runs.reschedule(\"run_1234\", { delay: \"1h\" });\n```\n\n## TTL\n\nYou can set a TTL (time to live) when triggering a task, which will automatically expire the run if it hasn't started within the specified time. This is useful for ensuring that a run doesn't get stuck in the queue for too long, or for time-sensitive tasks.\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e With this release, we're now setting a default TTL on development runs to 10m. This will prevent the issue where running the `trigger.dev dev` CLI command after not using it for awhile would result in an avalanche of built-up runs.\n\n```ts\nimport { myTask } from \"./trigger/myTasks\";\n\n// Expire the run if it hasn't started within 1 hour\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { ttl: \"1h\" });\n\n// If you specify a number, it will be treated as seconds\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { ttl: 3600 }); // 1 hour\n```\n\n## Delayed runs with TTL\n\nWhen you use both `delay` and `ttl`, the TTL will start counting down from the time the run is enqueued, not from the time the run is triggered.\n\nSo for example, when using the following code:\n\n```ts\nawait myTask.trigger({ some: \"data\" }, { delay: \"10m\", ttl: \"1h\" });\n```\n\nThe timeline would look like this:\n\n1. The run is created at 12:00:00\n2. The run is enqueued at 12:10:00\n3. The TTL starts counting down from 12:10:00\n4. If the run hasn't started by 13:10:00, it will be expired\n\nFor this reason, the `ttl` option only accepts durations and not absolute timestamps.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump This can lead to bloated applications, or worse, build failures because of some esoteric dependency that doesn't work when included in a Next.js 14.2.4 project (for example).\n\nAs of `v3.0.0-beta.41`, you can now trigger tasks using the `tasks.trigger` SDK function, passing in the type of the task only as a generic parameter:\n\n```ts Next.js API route\nimport { tasks } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport type { emailSequence } from \"~/trigger/emails\";\n//     ð **type-only** import\n\n//app/email/route.ts\nexport async function POST(request: Request) {\n  //get the JSON from the request\n  const data = await request.json();\n\n  // Pass the task type to `trigger()` as a generic argument, giving you full type checking\n  const handle = await tasks.trigger\u003ctypeof emailSequence\u003e(\"email-sequence\", {\n    //                                                      ð this ID is fully type safe as well\n    to: data.email,\n    name: data.name,\n  });\n\n  //return a success response with the handle\n  return Response.json(handle);\n}\n```\n\nBy importing only the type of the task, any dependencies the task has are not included in the build, and you get full type checking on the task payload, ID, and output.\n\nThis works with `batchTrigger` as well:\n\n```ts Next.js API route\nimport { tasks } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport type { emailSequence } from \"~/trigger/emails\";\n//     ð **type-only** import\n\n//app/email/route.ts\nexport async function POST(request: Request) {\n  //get the JSON from the request\n  const data = await request.json();\n\n  // Pass the task type to `batchTrigger()` as a generic argument, giving you full type checking\n  const batchHandle = await tasks.batchTrigger\u003ctypeof emailSequence\u003e(\n    \"email-sequence\",\n    data.users.map((u) =\u003e ({ payload: { to: u.email, name: u.name } }))\n  );\n\n  //return a success response with the handle\n  return Response.json(batchHandle);\n}\n```\n\nIn addition, the `handle` returned from `trigger` and `batchTrigger` now carries extra type information about the output of the task, which can be used to retrieve the run output in a typesafe way:\n\n```ts\nimport { tasks, runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport type { emailSequence } from \"~/trigger/emails\";\n//     ð **type-only** import\n\nasync function main(email: string, name: string) {\n  // Pass the task type to `trigger()` as a generic argument, giving you full type checking\n  const handle = await tasks.trigger\u003ctypeof emailSequence\u003e(\"email-sequence\", {\n    to: email,\n    name,\n  });\n\n  const run = await runs.retrieve(handle);\n\n  return run.output; // ð run.output is now typed\n}\n```\n\nThere's more! We included a polling helper function to the `runs` SDK module, which can be used to poll for the completion of a task run:\n\n```ts\nimport { tasks, runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport type { emailSequence } from \"~/trigger/emails\";\n//     ð **type-only** import\n\nasync function main(email: string, name: string) {\n  // Pass the task type to `trigger()` as a generic argument, giving you full type checking\n  const handle = await tasks.trigger\u003ctypeof emailSequence\u003e(\"email-sequence\", {\n    to: email,\n    name,\n  });\n\n  // Poll for the completion of the task run\n  const run = await runs.poll(handle, { pollIntervalMs: 1000 });\n\n  return run.output; // ð run.output is now typed and complete\n}\n```\n\nWe've also added a `triggerAndPoll` helper function to the `tasks` SDK module, which can be used to trigger a task and poll for the completion of the task run in one go:\n\n```ts\nimport { tasks } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport type { emailSequence } from \"~/trigger/emails\";\n\nasync function main(email: string, name: string) {\n  // Pass the task type to `triggerAndPoll()` as a generic argument, giving you full type checking\n  const run = await tasks.triggerAndPoll\u003ctypeof emailSequence\u003e(\n    \"email-sequence\",\n    {\n      to: email,\n      name,\n    },\n    {\n      pollIntervalMs: 1000,\n    }\n  );\n\n  return run.output; // ð run.output is now typed and complete\n}\n```\n\n\u003e [!NOTE]\n\u003e These new SDK functions are meant to be used from your server-side code only.\n\u003e They also aren't meant to replace `Task.triggerAndWait` or `Task.batchTriggerAndWait` when running inside another task.\n\nYou'll find these updates in the `@trigger.dev/sdk@3.0.0-beta.41` package. Give it a try and let us know what you think, or if we've missed anything!\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump This means you can schedule tasks in specific timezones and it automatically adjusts for Daylight Saving Time.\n\nWe've also made it compulsory to use a `deduplicationKey` when creating a schedule in code, and introduced some limits to the number of schedules you can create.\n\nRun this command in your repo to easily upgrade:\n\n```sh\nnpx trigger.dev@beta update\n```\n\n## Timezones\n\nWhen you create a schedule you can specify the timezone in IANA format, or leave it as `UTC`.\n\nExamples of IANA timezones are `America/New_York`, `Europe/London`, `Asia/Tokyo`, etc.\n\nIf you specify one of these then the schedule will automatically adjust when Daylight Saving Time starts and ends.\n\nThis is especially useful if you're [scheduling tasks for your users](https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks-scheduled#dynamic-schedules-or-multi-tenant-schedules). We've also added an SDK function to get all the possible timezones, this can be used to show a dropdown in your UI.\n\n```ts\nconst timezones = await schedules.timezones();\n```\n\n## In the dashboard\n\nWhen creating a schedule in the dashboard you can specify the timezone:\n\n![Trigger.dev dashboard](/changelog/scheduled-task-timezones/create-schedule.png)\n\nEverywhere in the dashboard where we show schedules we show the timezone (default is \"UTC\") and the time of the last and next run in that timezone.\n\n## Deduplication key and limits\n\nWe strongly recommend you create non-dynamic schedules in the dashboard UI. It means it's easier to toggle environments on and off and won't be confusing when your code doesn't match the state in the dashboard.\n\nWe've made a change to the SDK so that we now require you to provide a `deduplicationKey` when creating a schedule in code. If you use the same `deduplicationKey` more than once it will update the schedule rather than creating a new one. This is to prevent you from accidentally creating multiple schedules for the same task. There were several users who created thousands of duplicate schedules because they were running the create schedule code when their app started.\n\nWe've also introduced [some limits](https://trigger.dev/docs/limits#schedules) to the number of schedules you can create. The free limit is 5 schedules. Paid plans will have higher limits when they launch next month. For now, you can request more on the schedules page. We've temporarily increased the limits for existing users who were already over 5 and didn't have lots of duplicates.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Timezones","to":"#timezones","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"In the dashboard","to":"#in-the-dashboard","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Deduplication key and limits","to":"#deduplication-key-and-limits","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/scheduled-task-timezones/scheduled-task-timezones.mdx"},{"markdown":{"code":"var Component=(()=\u003e{var d=Object.create;var o=Object.defineProperty;var u=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor;var g=Object.getOwnPropertyNames;var m=Object.getPrototypeOf,p=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;var y=(t,e)=\u003e()=\u003e(e||t((e={exports:{}}).exports,e),e.exports),b=(t,e)=\u003e{for(var a in e)o(t,a,{get:e[a],enumerable:!0})},i=(t,e,a,s)=\u003e{if(e\u0026\u0026typeof e==\"object\"||typeof e==\"function\")for(let r of g(e))!p.call(t,r)\u0026\u0026r!==a\u0026\u0026o(t,r,{get:()=\u003ee[r],enumerable:!(s=u(e,r))||s.enumerable});return t};var v=(t,e,a)=\u003e(a=t!=null?d(m(t)):{},i(e||!t||!t.__esModule?o(a,\"default\",{value:t,enumerable:!0}):a,t)),w=t=\u003ei(o({},\"__esModule\",{value:!0}),t);var c=y((k,l)=\u003e{l.exports=_jsx_runtime});var j={};b(j,{default:()=\u003ex});var n=v(c());function h(t){let e=Object.assign({p:\"p\",a:\"a\",img:\"img\"},t.components);return(0,n.jsxs)(n.Fragment,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:'You can now rollback to a previous v3 deployment from the \"Deployments\" page.'}),`\n`,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:'This feature is useful when you need to revert to a previous deployment due to a bug or other issue. Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"We've added first-class support for getting runs using the SDK in version `3.0.0-beta.36`. The `list` function is especially nice as we're using some pretty neat tricks to make it really easy to paginate through runs.\n\nIf you haven't used any of the management functions before, [the overview](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/overview) which includes instructions on authentication is a good starting point.\n\nRun this command in your repo to easily upgrade:\n\n```sh\nnpx trigger.dev@beta update\n```\n\n## runs.retrieve()\n\n```ts\nimport { runs, APIError } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\n//run IDs start with \"run_\"\nasync function getRun(id: string) {\n  try {\n    const run = await runs.retrieve(id);\n  } catch (error) {\n    if (error instanceof ApiError) {\n      console.error(\n        `API error: ${error.status}, ${error.headers}, ${error.body}`\n      );\n    } else {\n      console.error(`Unknown error: ${error.message}`);\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\nYou get lots of useful information about the run including:\n\n- `status`: (e.g. `QUEUED`, `EXECUTING`, `COMPLETED`, `FAILED`, etc)\n- `payload`: The payload that was sent to the run\n- `output`: The output of the run, if it has completed\n- `startedAt`: When the run was started\n- `finishedAt`: When the run finished, if it has completed\n- `attempts`: Information about each attempt, including the status and any error.\n\n[Full reference docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/runs/retrieve).\n\n## runs.list()\n\n### Auto-pagination\n\nDealing with list pagination is usually a pain. You get a bunch of items back, then you have to make another request to get the next page, and so on. We've made this super easy with the `list` function. You can just use a `for await` loop to iterate through every single matching run.\n\n```ts\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nasync function fetchAllRuns() {\n  const allRuns = [];\n\n  for await (const run of runs.list({ limit: 10 })) {\n    allRuns.push(run);\n  }\n\n  return allRuns;\n}\n```\n\nBe warned: this will go through every single run, so you should break out of the loop\nwhen you have what you need. Or at least use a filter to only get the runs you're interested in.\n\n### Using getNextPage()\n\nAlternatively, you can get a page then use `getNextPage()` to get the next page.\n\n```ts\nimport { runs } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nasync function fetchRuns() {\n  let page = await runs.list({ limit: 10 });\n\n  for (const run of page.data) {\n    console.log(run);\n  }\n\n  while (page.hasNextPage()) {\n    page = await page.getNextPage();\n    // ... do something with the next page\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Filtering\n\nYou can use advanced filtering when listing runs. For example, to get all completed runs in the last year:\n\n```ts\nfor await (const run of runs.list({\n  status: [\"COMPLETED\"],\n  period: \"1y\",\n})) {\n  console.log(run);\n}\n```\n\nOr just `encode-video` tasks in the past day, that aren't tests and failed:\n\n```ts\nfor await (const run of runs.list({\n  taskIdentifier: \"encode-video\",\n  status: [\"FAILED\", \"CRASHED\", \"INTERRUPTED\", \"SYSTEM_FAILURE\"],\n  period: \"1d\",\n  isTest: false,\n})) {\n  console.log(run);\n}\n```\n\n[Full reference docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/runs/list).\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump An attempt is an execution of your code, if the attempt succeeds then the run will succeed. If the attempt fails then the run will be retried with more attempts until it succeeds or the maximum number of attempts is reached.\n\nYou should read the [Errors \u0026 Retrying guide](https://trigger.dev/docs/errors-retrying). If you apply the guidance you will achieve highly reliable runs.\n\n## What's changed and why is it better?\n\nWhen we first shipped v3 this is how attempts worked:\n\n1. Your run is taken from the queue on the platform.\n2. We create a run attempt on the platform.\n3. We spin up a new worker to execute your run.\n4. The worker runs (hopefully).\n5. The attempt succeeds or fails.\n6. Failed attempts go back into the queue.\n7. Repeat 1â6.\n\nThis had a couple of problems:\n\n- If the worker failed to start then there'd be a hung attempt. We automatically fail attempts that haven't communicated with the platform recently so it would try again.\n- Each attempt needed to go back into the queue which is innefficient and causes load on the platform.\n- If an attempt didn't start it would count againt your run's attempt limit.\n\nWe've moved creating run attempts to the worker, so now:\n\n1. Your run is taken from the queue on the platform.\n2. We spin up a new worker to execute your run.\n3. The worker creates a run attempt via the platform.\n4. The worker runs (hopefully).\n5. The attempt succeeds or fails.\n6. Failed attempts are retried by the worker, no need to be requeued.\n7. Repeat 3â6.\n\nThis is far more reliable because attempts are only created when the worker is actually running. It's also more efficient because we don't need to requeue failed attempts. Win win.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"Run Component;","frontmatter":{},"errors":[],"matter":{"content":"From v3 SDK version `3.0.0-beta.34` we have a fully-featured SDK for managing environment variables as well as a convenient way of syncing them from other services. [Read the full docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/deploy-environment-variables#in-your-code).\n\n### Directly manipulating environment variables\n\nYou can directly use SDK functions to manipulate environment variables. Here is a list of available functions:\n\n| Function                                                                   | Description                                                 |\n| -------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------- |\n| [envvars.list()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/envvars/list)         | List all environment variables                              |\n| [envvars.upload()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/envvars/import)     | Upload multiple env vars. You can override existing values. |\n| [envvars.create()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/envvars/create)     | Create a new environment variable                           |\n| [envvars.retrieve()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/envvars/retrieve) | Retrieve an environment variable                            |\n| [envvars.update()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/envvars/update)     | Update a single environment variable                        |\n| [envvars.del()](https://trigger.dev/docs/management/envvars/delete)        | Delete a single environment variable                        |\n\n### Syncing environment variables from other services\n\nInstead of using the SDK functions above it's much easier to use our `resolveEnvVars` function in your `trigger.config` file.\n\nIn this example we're using env vars from [Infisical](https://infisical.com/). You can use this with any secrets manager or environment variable provider.\n\n```ts /trigger.config.ts\nimport type {\n  TriggerConfig,\n  ResolveEnvironmentVariablesFunction,\n} from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\n//This runs when you run the deploy command or the dev command\nexport const resolveEnvVars: ResolveEnvironmentVariablesFunction = async ({\n  //the project ref (starting with \"proj_\")\n  projectRef,\n  //any existing env vars from a .env file or Trigger.dev\n  env,\n  //\"dev\", \"staging\", or \"prod\"\n  environment,\n}) =\u003e {\n  //the existing environment variables from Trigger.dev (or your local .env file)\n  if (\n    env.INFISICAL_CLIENT_ID === undefined ||\n    env.INFISICAL_CLIENT_SECRET === undefined\n  ) {\n    //returning undefined won't modify the existing env vars\n    return;\n  }\n\n  const client = new InfisicalClient({\n    clientId: env.INFISICAL_CLIENT_ID,\n    clientSecret: env.INFISICAL_CLIENT_SECRET,\n  });\n\n  const secrets = It's fundamentally better for writing background jobs than v2 and similar products from competitors.\n\nMore importantly, we're at the point now where we think it would be a mistake for someone creating a new project to use v2 when they can choose v3.\n\nView the [v3 feature matrix](https://trigger.dev/docs/feature-matrix) to see what is currently supported. `v3.0.0-beta.15` with some breaking changes, fixes, and API improvements.\n\n## Breaking changes\n\n`v3.0.0-beta.15` updates the `Task.trigger`, `Task.batchTrigger` and their `*AndWait` variants to use the first parameter for the payload/items, and the second parameter for options.\n\nBefore:\n\n```ts\nawait yourTask.trigger({\n  payload: { foo: \"bar\" },\n  options: { idempotencyKey: \"key_1234\" },\n});\nawait yourTask.triggerAndWait({\n  payload: { foo: \"bar\" },\n  options: { idempotencyKey: \"key_1234\" },\n});\n\nawait yourTask.batchTrigger({\n  items: [{ payload: { foo: \"bar\" } }, { payload: { foo: \"baz\" } }],\n});\nawait yourTask.batchTriggerAndWait({\n  items: [{ payload: { foo: \"bar\" } }, { payload: { foo: \"baz\" } }],\n});\n```\n\nAfter:\n\n```ts\nawait yourTask.trigger({ foo: \"bar\" }, { idempotencyKey: \"key_1234\" });\nawait yourTask.triggerAndWait({ foo: \"bar\" }, { idempotencyKey: \"key_1234\" });\n\nawait yourTask.batchTrigger([\n  { payload: { foo: \"bar\" } },\n  { payload: { foo: \"baz\" } },\n]);\nawait yourTask.batchTriggerAndWait([\n  { payload: { foo: \"bar\" } },\n  { payload: { foo: \"baz\" } },\n]);\n```\n\nWe've also changed the API of the `triggerAndWait` result. Before, if the subtask that was triggered finished with an error, we would automatically \"rethrow\" the error in the parent task.\n\nNow instead we're returning a `TaskRunResult` object that allows you to discriminate between successful and failed runs in the subtask:\n\nBefore:\n\n```ts\ntry {\n  const result = await yourTask.triggerAndWait({ foo: \"bar\" });\n\n  // result is the output of your task\n  console.log(\"result\", result);\n} catch (error) {\n  // handle subtask errors here\n}\n```\n\nAfter:\n\n```ts\nconst result = await yourTask.triggerAndWait({ foo: \"bar\" });\n\nif (result.ok) {\n  console.log(`Run ${result.id} succeeded with output`, result.output);\n} else {\n  console.log(`Run ${result.id} failed with error`, result.error);\n}\n```\n\n## Fixes\n\n- Fixes an issue when using idempotency keys with `triggerAndWait` and `batchTriggerAndWait` failing to resume if the idempotency key matched an already completed run.\n- Add additional logging around cleaning up dev workers, and always kill them after 5 seconds if they haven't already exited\n- Fixes an issue that caused failed tasks when resuming after calling `triggerAndWait` or `batchTriggerAndWait` in prod/staging (this doesn't effect dev).\n\nThe version of Node.js we use for deployed workers (latest 20) would crash with an out-of-memory error when the checkpoint was restored. This crash does not happen on Node 18x or Node21x, so we've decided to upgrade the worker version to Node.js21x, to mitigate this issue.\n\nYou'll need to re-deploy to production to fix the issue.\n\n## Improvements\n\n- We no longer limit individual task concurrency when no concurrency limit is set for the task or the queue the task belongs to. If you haven't already you should [sign up for the v3 waitlist](/v3-early-access).\n\nAt the end I'll reveal what schedule the cron pattern in the image above, `0 17 * * 5`, represents. You cron nerds need closure.\n\nIn the video my scheduled task posts a GIF to Slack every minute.\n\n\u003ciframe\n  src=\"https://customer-b7sn6wc8h2wusre0.cloudflarestream.com/8bac7841605e19408883b11f958e65e3/iframe?poster=https%3A%2F%2Fcustomer-b7sn6wc8h2wusre0.cloudflarestream.com%2F8bac7841605e19408883b11f958e65e3%2Fthumbnails%2Fthumbnail.jpg%3Ftime%3D%26height%3D600\"\n  width=\"100%\"\n  height=\"466px\"\n  allow=\"autoplay\"\n  allowFullScreen={true}\n\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\nFeatures\n\n- Define your task in code using `schedules.task()`\n- Attach many schedules (across environments) to each task in the dashboard.\n- Attach schedules using the SDK (you can do dynamic things like a schedule for each of your users using `externalId`)\n- List, view, edit, disable, re-enable, create and delete using the dashboard, SDK and REST API.\n- Use AI to help you create cron patterns in the dashboard.\n\nFull docs here: https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks-scheduled\n\n## An example scheduled task\n\nThis is the scheduled task code from the video above.\n\n```ts /trigger/random-time-gif.ts\nimport { WebClient } from \"@slack/web-api\";\nimport { retry, schedules } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\n\nconst slack = new WebClient(process.env.SLACK_BOT_TOKEN);\n\n//define the task using schedules.task()\nexport const randomTimeGif = schedules.task({\n  id: \"random-time-gif\",\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    //Get 25 GIFs related to \"time\" from the giphy API\n    const randomGifResponse = await retry.fetch(\n      `https://api.giphy.com/v1/gifs/search?api_key=${process.env.GIPHY_API_KEY}\u0026q=time\u0026limit=25\u0026offset=0\u0026rating=g\u0026lang=en\u0026bundle=messaging_non_clips`\n    );\n    const json = await randomGifResponse.json();\n\n    //pick a random GIF URL from the results\n    const resultCount = json.data.length;\n    const randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * resultCount);\n    const url = json.data[randomIndex]?.url;\n\n    if (!url) {\n      throw new Error(\"No gif found\");\n    }\n\n    //post to a Slack channel\n    const result = await slack.chat.postMessage({\n      text: url,\n      channel: process.env.SLACK_CHANNEL_ID!,\n    });\n\n    return { success: true };\n  },\n});\n```\n\nAs shown in the video, you can attach a schedule to this task in the dashboard. This is great for most use cases.\n\n## Dynamic schedules (or multi-tenant)\n\nUsing the SDK you can do more advanced scheduling. For example, you could let your users define a schedule that they want to post GIFs to their own Slack workspace channel.\n\nFirst take what we had before and modify the task slightly:\n\n```ts /trigger/scheduled-slack-gif.ts focus=9:16,22:24,38,41\nimport { WebClient } from \"@slack/web-api\";\nimport { retry, schedules } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { db } from \"@/db\";\n\n//define the task using schedules.task()\nexport const scheduledSlackGifs = schedules.task({\n  id: \"scheduled-slack-gifs\",\n  run: async (payload) =\u003e {\n    //we'll set the externalId to a row in our database when we create the schedule\n    if (!payload.externalId) {\n      throw new Error(\"externalId is required\");\n    }\n\n    //get the details of what the user wants\n    const { slackToken, slackChannelId, gifSearchQuery } =\n      await db.getGifSchedule(payload.externalId);\n\n    //Get 25 GIFs related to \"time\" from the giphy API\n    const randomGifResponse = await retry.fetch(\n      `https://api.giphy.com/v1/gifs/search?api_key=${\n        process.env.GIPHY_API_KEY\n      }\u0026q=${encodeURIComponent(\n        gifSearchQuery\n      )}=25\u0026offset=0\u0026rating=g\u0026lang=en\u0026bundle=messaging_non_clips`\n    );\n    const json = await randomGifResponse.json();\n\n    //pick a random GIF URL from the results\n    const resultCount = json.data.length;\n    const randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * resultCount);\n    const url = json.data[randomIndex]?.url;\n\n    if (!url) {\n      throw new Error(\"No gif found\");\n    }\n\n    //post to a Slack channel\n    const slack = new WebClient(slackToken);\n    const result = await slack.chat.postMessage({\n      text: url,\n      channel: slackChannelId,\n    });\n\n    return { success: true };\n  },\n});\n```\n\nThen in your backend code you need to register a schedule for this task. This is a Next.js server action but the only thing that matters is that it's on your server:\n\n```ts\n\"use server\";\n\nimport { scheduledSlackGifs } from \"@/trigger/scheduled-user-gifs\";\nimport { schedules } from \"@trigger.dev/sdk/v3\";\nimport { db } from \"@/db\";\n\nexport async function registerSchedule(\n  userId: string,\n  cron: string,\n  searchQuery: string\n) {\n  try {\n    //create a record for the GIF schedule for this user\n    const row = await db.createGifSchedule(userId, searchQuery);\n\n    //create a new schedule for this GIF schedule\n    const createdSchedule = await schedules.create({\n      task: scheduledSlackGifs.id,\n      cron,\n      //the row id, so we can retrieve the row inside the run\n      externalId: row.id,\n      //don't allow multiple shedules for the same GIF schedule\n      deduplicationKey: row.id,\n    });\n\n    return { scheduleId: createdSchedule.id };\n  } catch (error) {\n    console.error(error);\n    return {\n      error: \"something went wrong\",\n    };\n  }\n}\n```\n\nThe user has defined their own reminder frequency and what kind of GIFs they want.\n\n[Read the full docs](https://trigger.dev/docs/tasks-scheduled) for everything that scheduled tasks allow.\n\nSo the cron pattern `0 17 * * 5` is every Friday at 5pm (UTC). I hope that helps you sleep at night.\n","data":{},"isEmpty":false,"excerpt":""}},"contents":{"depth":0,"title":"Jump to","to":"#","style":"header","children":[{"depth":2,"title":"An example scheduled task","to":"#an-example-scheduled-task","children":[]},{"depth":2,"title":"Dynamic schedules (or multi-tenant)","to":"#dynamic-schedules-or-multi-tenant","children":[]}]},"filename":"/changelog/scheduled-tasks/scheduled-tasks.mdx"}]},"routes/changelog":null},"actionData":null,"errors":null},"future":{"v2_dev":false,"unstable_postcss":false,"unstable_tailwind":false,"v2_errorBoundary":true,"v2_headers":false,"v2_meta":true,"v2_normalizeFormMethod":false,"v2_routeConvention":true}};</script><script type="module" async="">import "/build/manifest-7F358A19.js";
